{{pp-vandalism|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox hurricane | Name = Hurricane Sandy | Type = hurricane | Year = 2012 | Basin = Atl | Image location = Sandy Oct 25 2012 0320Z.png | Image name = Hurricane Sandy at peak intensity just before landfall in [[Cuba]] on October 25 | Formed = October 22, 2012 | Dissipated = November 2, 2012 | Extratropical = October 29 | 1-min winds = 100 | Pressure = 940 | Damages = 68700 | Damagespost = [[List of costliest Atlantic hurricanes|Fourth-costliest]] [[hurricane]] in U.S. history | Fatalities = 233 total | Areas = [[Greater Antilles]], [[Bahamas]], most of the eastern [[United States]] (especially the coastal [[Mid-Atlantic States]]), [[Bermuda]], eastern [[Canada]] | Hurricane season = [[2012 Atlantic hurricane season]] | Related = {{Hurricane Sandy related}} }}
'''Hurricane Sandy''' (unofficially referred to as '''Superstorm Sandy''')<ref name="not The Big One">{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/18/sandy-hurricane-damage-co_n_5842958.html|title=Report Warns That Superstorm Sandy Was Not 'The Big One'|author=Kate Sheppard|publisher=Huffington Post|date=September 18, 2014|accessdate=April 18, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Superstorm Sandy Anniversary">{{cite web|url=https://weather.com/storms/hurricane/news/superstorm-sandy-anniversary-20141029|title=Superstorm Sandy Anniversary: Remembering Hurricane Sandy Two Years Later|author=Eric Zerkel|publisher=[[The Weather Company]]|date=October 29, 2014|accessdate=April 18, 2017}}</ref> was the deadliest and most destructive [[tropical cyclone|hurricane]] of the [[2012 Atlantic hurricane season]]. Inflicting nearly $70 billion (2012 USD) in damage, it was the second-costliest hurricane on record in the United States until surpassed by Hurricanes [[Hurricane Harvey|Harvey]] and [[Hurricane Maria|Maria]] in [[2017 Atlantic hurricane season|2017]]. The eighteenth [[Tropical cyclone naming|named storm]], tenth [[hurricane]], and second [[major hurricane]] of the year, Sandy was a [[Saffir–Simpson hurricane wind scale#Category 3|Category 3]] storm at its peak intensity when it made landfall in [[Cuba]].<ref name="SandyTCR">{{cite report|author=Blake, Eric S|author2=Kimberlain, Todd B|author3=Berg, Robert J|author4=Cangialosi, John P|author5=Beven II, John L|date=February 12, 2013|type=Tropical Cyclone Report|format=PDF|title=Hurricane Sandy: October 22 – 29, 2012|author6=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=February 17, 2013|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL182012_Sandy}}|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6EVJRUQAQ?url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/data/tcr/AL182012_Sandy.pdf|publisher=United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Weather Service|archivedate=February 17, 2013}}</ref> While it was a [[Saffir–Simpson Hurricane Scale#Category 2|Category 2]] hurricane off the coast of the Northeastern United States, the storm became the largest [[North Atlantic tropical cyclone|Atlantic hurricane]] on record (as measured by diameter, with tropical-storm-force winds spanning {{convert|900|mi|km}}).<ref name="Largest Atlantic hurricanes">{{cite web|last1=Masters|first1=Jeff|title=Will Global Warming Create Larger Hurricanes?|url=https://www.wunderground.com/cat6/will-global-warming-create-larger-hurricanes|publisher=Weather Underground|accessdate=May 7, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Sandy Brings Hurricane-Force Gusts After New Jersey Landfall|url=http://washpost.bloomberg.com/Story?docId=1376-MCMWP11A1I4H01-2DUORIV7RUREVIT7O7L4UFGTVF|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130612152712/http://washpost.bloomberg.com/Story?docId=1376-MCMWP11A1I4H01-2DUORIV7RUREVIT7O7L4UFGTVF|dead-url=yes|archive-date=June 12, 2013|publisher=Washington Post|accessdate=October 30, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Hurricane Sandy Grows To Largest Atlantic Tropical Storm Ever|url=http://boston.cbslocal.com/2012/10/28/hurricane-sandy-grows-to-largest-atlantic-tropical-storm-ever/|publisher=[[WBZ-TV]]|accessdate=January 7, 2013}}</ref> At least 233 people were killed along the path of the storm in eight countries.<ref name="Diakakis et al 2013">{{cite journal |title= Hurricane Sandy mortality in the Caribbean and continental North America |author1= Diakakis M. |author2= Deligiannakis G. |author3= Katsetsiadou K. |author4= Lekkas E. |journal= Disaster Prevention and Management: an International Journal|year=2015|volume=24|issue=1|pages=132 |doi=10.1108/DPM-05-2014-0082|url=http://www.emeraldinsight.com/doi/abs/10.1108/DPM-05-2014-0082}}</ref><ref>Cumulative total of death toll by country; see chart.</ref>
Sandy developed from a [[tropical wave]] in the western Caribbean Sea on October 22, quickly strengthened, and was upgraded to Tropical Storm Sandy six hours later. Sandy moved slowly northward toward the [[Greater Antilles]] and gradually intensified. On October 24, Sandy became a hurricane, made landfall near [[Kingston, Jamaica]], re-emerged a few hours later into the Caribbean Sea and strengthened into a Category 2 hurricane. On October 25, Sandy hit Cuba as a Category 3 hurricane, then weakened to a Category 1 hurricane. Early on October 26, Sandy moved through the Bahamas.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hurricane Sandy storms through Bahamas, Central Florida on alert|url=http://www.cfnews13.com/content/news/cfnews13/news/article.html/content/news/articles/cfn/2012/10/25/hurricane_sandy_movi.html|publisher=[[Central Florida News 13]]|accessdate=October 26, 2012}}</ref> On October 27, Sandy briefly weakened to a tropical storm and then restrengthened to a Category 1 hurricane. Early on October 29, Sandy curved west-northwest (the "left turn" or "left hook") and then<ref>{{cite web|title=Post-Tropical Cyclone SANDY Update Statement |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/text/refresh/MIATCUAT3+shtml/292256.shtml |publisher=[[National Hurricane Center]] |accessdate=October 29, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121101013948/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/text/refresh/MIATCUAT3%2Bshtml/292256.shtml |archive-date=November 1, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> moved ashore near [[Brigantine, New Jersey]], just to the northeast of [[Atlantic City]], as a [[post-tropical cyclone]] with hurricane-force winds.<ref name="SandyTCR"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/10/29/us/tropical-weather-sandy/index.html|title=Sandy wreaks havoc across Northeast; at least 11 dead|publisher=CNN|date=October 30, 2012}}</ref>
In [[Jamaica]], winds left 70% of residents without electricity, blew roofs off buildings, killed one person, and caused about $100 million (2012 USD) in damage. Sandy's outer bands brought flooding to [[Haiti]], killing at least 54, causing food shortages, and leaving about 200,000 homeless; the hurricane also caused two deaths in the [[Dominican Republic]]. In [[Puerto Rico]], one man was swept away by a swollen river. In Cuba, there was extensive coastal flooding and wind damage inland, destroying some 15,000 homes, killing 11, and causing $2 billion (2012 USD) in damage. Sandy caused two deaths and an estimated $700 million (2012 USD) in damage in [[The Bahamas]].
In the United States, Hurricane Sandy affected 24 [[U.S. state|states]], including the entire eastern seaboard from [[Florida]] to [[Maine]] and west across the [[Appalachian Mountains]] to [[Michigan]] and [[Wisconsin]], with particularly severe damage in [[New Jersey]] and [[New York (state)|New York]]. Its [[storm surge]] hit [[New York City]] on October 29, flooding streets, tunnels and subway lines and cutting power in and around the city.<ref>[http://news.blogs.cnn.com/2012/10/29/hurricane-sandy-strengthens-to-85-mph/ "Superstorm Sandy causes at least 9 U.S. deaths as it slams East Coast"], CNN</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap1000000088170/article/eli-manning-deals-with-superstorm-sandy-flooding|title=Eli Manning deals with Superstorm Sandy flooding|work=[[National Football League]]|date=October 31, 2012|accessdate=October 31, 2012}}</ref> Damage in the United States amounted to $65 billion (2012 USD).<ref name="costliest" /> In Canada, two were killed in Ontario, and the storm caused an estimated $100 million ([[Canadian dollar|2012 CAD]]) in damage throughout Ontario and Quebec.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/business/story/2012/11/28/sandy-ontario-quebec.html|title=Sandy caused $100M in Canadian insurance claims|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=November 28, 2012}}</ref> {{TOC limit|4}}
==Meteorological history== {{main|Meteorological history of Hurricane Sandy}} {{storm path|Sandy 2012 track.png}} Hurricane Sandy began as a low pressure system which developed sufficient organized [[convection (meteorology)|convection]] to be classified as Tropical Depression Eighteen on October 22 south of [[Kingston, Jamaica]].<ref name="disc1">{{cite report|author=Robbie Berg|author2=Lixion Avila|date=October 22, 2012|title=Tropical Depression Eighteen Discussion Number 1|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 23, 2012|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.discus.001.shtml?}}</ref> It moved slowly at first due to a [[ridge (meteorology)|ridge]] to the north. Low [[wind shear]] and warm [[sea surface temperature|waters]] allowed for strengthening,<ref name="disc1"/> and the system was [[North Atlantic hurricane naming list|named]] Tropical Storm Sandy late on October 22.<ref>{{cite report|author=Richard Pasch|date=October 22, 2012|title=Tropical Storm Sandy Discussion Number 2|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 23, 2012|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.discus.002.shtml?}}</ref> Early on October 24, an [[eye (cyclone)|eye]] began developing, and it was moving steadily northward due to an approaching [[trough (meteorology)|trough]].<ref>{{cite report|author=Jack Beven|date=October 24, 2012|title=Tropical Storm Sandy Discussion Number 7|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 24, 2012|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.discus.007.shtml?}}</ref> Later that day, the [[National Hurricane Center|National Hurricane Center (NHC)]] upgraded Sandy to hurricane status about {{convert|65|mi|km|abbr=on}} south of Kingston, Jamaica.<ref>{{cite report|author=Michael Brennan|date=October 24, 2012|title=Hurricane Sandy Discussion Number 9|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 24, 2012|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.discus.009.shtml?}}</ref> At about 1900 UTC that day, Sandy made [[landfall (meteorology)|landfall]] near Kingston with winds of about 85 mph (140 km/h).<ref>{{cite report|author=Todd Kimberlain|author2=James Franklin|date=October 24, 2002|title=Hurricane Sandy Tropical Cyclone Update|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 24, 2012|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.update.10241918.shtml?}}</ref> Just offshore Cuba, Sandy rapidly intensified to winds of 115 mph (185 km/h),<ref name="SandyTCR"/> and at that intensity it made landfall just west of [[Santiago de Cuba]] at 0525 UTC on October 25.<ref>{{cite report|author=Stacy Stewart|author2=Dave Roberts|date=October 25, 2012|title=Hurricane Sandy Tropical Cyclone Update|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 26, 2012|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.update.10250539.shtml?}}</ref> Operationally, Sandy was assessed to have peaked as a high-end Category 2 hurricane with maximum sustained winds of 110 mph (175 km/h).<ref name="SandyTCR" />
[[File:Hurricane sandy nasa satelite time lapse video.ogg|thumbnail|A time-lapse video made from NASA satellite images of Hurricane Sandy]] After Sandy exited Cuba, the structure became disorganized,<ref>{{cite report|author=Michael Brennan|date=October 25, 2012|title=Hurricane Sandy Discussion Number 14|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 26, 2012|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.discus.014.shtml?}}</ref> and it turned to the north-northwest over the Bahamas.<ref>{{cite report|author=Jack Beven|date=October 26, 2012|title=Hurricane Sandy Discussion Number 15|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 26, 2012|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.discus.015.shtml?}}</ref> By October 27, Sandy was no longer fully tropical, as evidenced by the development of frontal structures in the outer circulation.<ref name="SandyTCR" /> Despite strong shear, Sandy maintained convection due to influence from an approaching trough; the same that turned the hurricane to the northeast.<ref>{{cite report|author=Jack Beven|date=October 27, 2012|title=Hurricane Sandy Discussion Number 19|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 27, 2012|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.discus.019.shtml?}}</ref> After briefly weakening to a tropical storm,<ref>{{cite report|author=Jack Beven|date=October 27, 2012|title=Tropical Storm Sandy Discussion Number 20|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 27, 2012|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.discus.020.shtml?}}</ref> Sandy re-intensified into a hurricane,<ref>{{cite report|author=Daniel Brown|date=October 27, 2012|title=Hurricane Sandy Discussion Number 21|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 27, 2012|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.discus.021.shtml?}}</ref> and on October 28 an eye began redeveloping.<ref>{{cite report|author=Stacy Stewart|date=October 29, 2012|title=Hurricane Sandy Discussion Number 25|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 31, 2012|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.discus.025.shtml?}}</ref> The storm moved around an [[cold-core low|upper-level low]] over the eastern United States and also to the southwest of a ridge over [[Atlantic Canada]], turning it to the northwest.<ref name="disc28">{{cite report|author=Richard Pasch|author2=John Cangialosi|date=October 29, 2012|title=Hurricane Sandy Discussion Number 28|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 31, 2012|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.discus.028.shtml?}}</ref> Sandy briefly re-intensified to Category 2 intensity on the morning of October 29, around which time it had become an extremely large hurricane with a wind diameter of over 1,000 miles (1,609 km), and an unusually low central [[barometric pressure]] of 940 mbar, possibly due to the very large size of the system.<ref name="SandyTCR" /> This pressure set records for many cities across the [[Northeastern United States]] for the lowest [[barometric pressure|pressures]] ever observed.<ref>{{cite report|author=Stacy Stewart|date=October 29, 2012|title=Hurricane Sandy Discussion Number 29|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 31, 2012|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.discus.029.shtml?}}</ref> The convection diminished while the hurricane accelerated toward the New Jersey coast,<ref>{{cite report|author=Richard Knabb|author2=James Franklin|date=October 29, 2012|title=Hurricane Sandy Discussion Number 30|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 31, 2012|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.discus.030.shtml?}}</ref> and the cyclone was no longer tropical by 2100 UTC on October 29.<ref>{{cite report|author=Daniel Brown|author2=Dave Roberts|date=October 29, 2012|title=Post-Tropical Cyclone Sandy Tropical Cyclone Update|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 31, 2012|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.update.10292255.shtml?}}</ref> About 2½ hours later, Sandy made landfall near Brigantine, New Jersey,<ref>{{cite report|author=Daniel Brown|author2=Dave Roberts|date=October 30, 2012|title=Post-Tropical Cyclone Sandy Tropical Cyclone Update|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 31, 2012|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.update.10300002.shtml?}}</ref> with winds of 80 mph (130 km/h).<ref name="SandyTCR" /> During the next four days, Sandy's remnants drifted northward and then northeastward over [[Ontario]], before merging with another low pressure area over [[Eastern Canada]] on November 2.<ref name="SandyTCR" /><ref name="Sandy absorbed">{{cite web|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=11/02/2012&selmap=2012110218&maptype=satsfcnps|title=WPC surface analysis valid for 11/02/2017 at 18 UTC|publisher=NOAA's National Weather Service|date=November 2, 2011|accessdate=September 29, 2017}}</ref>
===Forecasts=== On October 23, 2012, the path of Hurricane Sandy was correctly predicted by the [[European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts]] (ECMWF) headquartered in [[Reading, Berkshire|Reading, England]] nearly eight days in advance of its striking the [[East Coast of the United States|American East Coast]]. The computer model noted that the storm would turn west towards land and strike the New York/New Jersey region on October 29, rather than turn east and head out to the open Atlantic as most hurricanes in this position do. By October 27, four days after the ECMWF made its prediction, the [[National Weather Service]] and [[National Hurricane Center]] confirmed the path of the hurricane predicted by the European model. The National Weather Service was criticized for not employing its higher-resolution forecast models the way that its European counterpart did. A hardware and software upgrade completed at the end of 2013 enabled the weather service to make more accurate predictions, and do so far more in advance than the technology in 2012 had allowed.<ref>{{cite news|last=Vergano|first=Dan|title=U.S. forecast's late arrival stirs weather tempest|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/weather/2012/10/30/sandy-hurricane-models/1668867/w|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=October 5, 2013|date=October 30, 2012}}</ref>
===Relation to global warming=== {{see also|Tropical cyclones and climate change}} According to [[NCAR]] senior climatologist [[Kevin E. Trenberth]], "The answer to the oft-asked question of whether an event is caused by [[global warming|climate change]] is that it is the wrong question. All weather events are affected by climate change because the environment in which they occur is warmer and moister than it used to be."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Trenberth|first=Kevin|title=Framing the way to relate climate extremes to climate change|journal=Climatic Change|date=March 2012|doi=10.1007/s10584-012-0441-5|url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/0008xl84w0743102/fulltext.pdf|volume=115|issue=2|pages=283–290}}</ref> Although [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]] meteorologist Martin Hoerling attributes Sandy to "little more than the coincidental alignment of a tropical storm with an extratropical storm",<ref name="Revkin">{{cite news|last=Andrew C.|first=Revkin|title=The #Frankenstorm in Climate Context|url=http://dotearth.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/10/28/the-frankenstorm-in-climate-context/|newspaper=The New York Times; Dot Earth|date=October 28, 2012}}</ref> Trenberth does agree that the storm was caused by "natural variability" but adds that it was "enhanced by global warming".<ref name="SurfTemps">{{cite web|last=Trenberth|first=Kevin|title=Hurricane Sandy mixes super-storm conditions with climate change|url=http://theconversation.edu.au/hurricane-sandy-mixes-super-storm-conditions-with-climate-change-10388|publisher=The Conversation|accessdate=October 29, 2012|quote=The sea surface temperatures along the Atlantic coast have been running at over 3[[°C]] above normal for a region extending 800 km off shore all the way from Florida to Canada. Global warming contributes 0.6°C to this. With every degree C, the water holding of the atmosphere goes up 7%, and the moisture provides fuel for the tropical storm, increases its intensity, and magnifies the rainfall by double that amount compared with normal conditions. Global climate change has contributed to the higher sea surface and ocean temperatures, and a warmer and moister atmosphere, and its effects are in the range of 5 to 10%. Natural variability and weather has provided the perhaps optimal conditions of a hurricane running into extra-tropical conditions to make for a huge intense storm, enhanced by global warming influences.}}</ref> One factor contributing to the storm's strength was abnormally warm [[sea surface temperatures]] offshore the [[East Coast of the United States]]—more than {{convert|3|C-change|F-change|sigfig=1}} above normal, to which global warming had contributed {{convert|0.6|C-change|F-change|sigfig=1}}.<ref name="SurfTemps" /> As the temperature of the atmosphere increases, the capacity to hold water increases, leading to stronger storms and higher rainfall amounts.<ref name="SurfTemps" />
As they move north, Atlantic hurricanes typically are forced east and out to sea by the [[Westerlies|Prevailing Westerlies]].<ref name=Masters>{{cite web|last=Masters|first=Jeff|title=Why did Hurricane Sandy take such an unusual track into New Jersey?|url=http://www.wunderground.com/blog/JeffMasters/comment.html?entrynum=2283|publisher=Weather Underground|accessdate=November 6, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103064238/http://www.wunderground.com/blog/JeffMasters/comment.html?entrynum=2283|archivedate=November 3, 2012|df=}}</ref> In Sandy's case, this typical pattern was [[Block (meteorology)|blocked]] by a ridge of high pressure over Greenland resulting in a negative [[North Atlantic Oscillation]], forming a kink in the jet stream, causing it to double back on itself off the East Coast. Sandy was caught up in this northwesterly flow.<ref name=Masters /> The blocking pattern over Greenland also stalled an [[Arctic front]] which combined with the cyclone.<ref name=Masters /> Mark Fischetti of ''[[Scientific American]]'' said that the jet stream's unusual shape was caused by [[Climate change in the Arctic|the melting of Arctic ice]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Did Climate Change Cause Hurricane Sandy?|last=Fischetti|first=Mark|date=October 30, 2012|url=http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/observations/2012/10/30/did-climate-change-cause-hurricane-sandy/}}</ref> Trenberth said that while a negative North Atlantic Oscillation and a blocking anticyclone were in place, the [[null hypothesis]] remained that this was just the natural variability of weather.<ref name=Revkin/> Sea level at New York and along the New Jersey coast [[Current sea level rise|has increased by nearly a foot]] (300 mm) over the last hundred years,<ref>{{cite journal|title=How to keep New York afloat|author=Velasquez-Manoff, Moises|publisher=Christian Science Monitor|date=November 9, 2006|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-154089560.html|accessdate=December 15, 2012}}</ref> which contributed to the [[storm surge]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Boxall and Neela Banerjee|first=Bettina|title=Sandy a galvanizing moment for climate change?|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-climate-politics-20121105,0,234626.story|accessdate=November 5, 2012|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=November 4, 2012}}</ref> Harvard geologist [[Daniel P. Schrag]] calls Hurricane Sandy's 13-foot (4 m) storm surge an example of what will, by mid-century, be the "new norm on the Eastern seaboard".<ref>{{cite news|last=Mason|first=Edward|title=Hello again, climate change|url=http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2012/11/hello-again-climate-change/|accessdate=November 7, 2012|newspaper=Harvard Gazette|date=November 6, 2012}}"He pointed out that since 2007, melted Arctic ice opened the Northwest Passage, a development that he believes could have a dramatic effect on weather patterns. Last spring's unseasonable warmth caused places like Rochester, Minn., to set record daytime highs. 'By midcentury, this will be the new normal,' Schrag predicted. 'How do you deal with extreme heat in the summer? It's going to be a challenge, but humans are adaptable. It's not going to be easy, just like a 13-foot storm surge will be the new norm on the Eastern seaboard.'"</ref>
==Preparations==
===Caribbean and Bermuda=== After the storm became a tropical cyclone on October 22, the [[Government of Jamaica]] issued a tropical storm watch for the entire island.<ref>{{cite report|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.public.001.shtml?|title=Tropical Depression Eighteen Advisory Number 1|author1=Robbie Berg |author2=Lixion Avila |date=October 22, 2012|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 24, 2012}}</ref> Early on October 23, the watch was replaced with a tropical storm warning and a hurricane watch was issued.<ref>{{cite report|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.public.004.shtml?|title=Tropical Storm Sandy Advisory Number 4|author=Daniel Brown|date=October 23, 2012|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 24, 2012}}</ref> At 1500 UTC, the hurricane watch was upgraded to a hurricane warning, while the tropical storm warning was discontinued.<ref name="advis5">{{cite report|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.public.004.shtml?|title=Tropical Storm Sandy Advisory Number 5|author=Richard Pasch|date=October 23, 2012|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 24, 2012}}</ref> In preparation of the storm, many residents stocked up on supplies and reinforced roofing material. Acting Prime Minister Peter Phillips urged people to take this storm seriously, and also to take care of their neighbors, especially the elderly, children, and disabled. Government officials shut down schools, government buildings, and the airport in Kingston on the day prior to the arrival of Sandy. Meanwhile, numerous and early curfews were put in place to protect residents, properties, and to prevent crime.<ref>{{cite news|last=McFadden|first=David|title=Jamaica prepares for Tropical Storm Sandy|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/tropical-storm-warning-jamaica-ahead-sandy|accessdate=November 26, 2012|newspaper=Associated Press|date=October 23, 2012}}</ref> Shortly after Jamaica issued its first watch on October 22, the [[Government of Haiti]] issued a tropical storm watch for Haiti.<ref>{{cite report|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.public.002.shtml?|title=Tropical Storm Sandy Advisory Number 2|author=Richard Pasch|date=October 22, 2012|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 24, 2012}}</ref> By late October 23, it was modified to a tropical storm warning.<ref>{{cite report|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.public_a.005.shtml?|title=Tropical Storm Sandy Advisory Number 5A|author=Richard Pasch|date=October 23, 2012|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 24, 2012}}</ref>
The [[Government of Cuba]] posted a hurricane watch for the [[Provinces of Cuba|Cuban Provinces]] of [[Camagüey Province|Camagüey]], [[Granma Province|Granma]], [[Guantánamo Province|Guantánamo]], [[Holguín Province|Holguín]], [[Las Tunas Province|Las Tunas]], and [[Santiago de Cuba Province|Santiago de Cuba]] at 1500 UTC on October 23.<ref name="advis5"/> Only three hours later, the hurricane watch was switched to a hurricane warning.<ref name="advis6">{{cite report|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.public.006.shtml?|title=Tropical Storm Sandy Advisory Number 6|author=Richard Pasch|date=October 23, 2012|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 24, 2012}}</ref> The [[Government of the Bahamas]], at 1500 UTC on October 23, issued a tropical storm watch for several Bahamian islands, including the [[Acklins]], [[Cat Island, Bahamas|Cat Island]], [[Crooked Island, Bahamas|Crooked Island]], [[Exuma]], [[Inagua]], [[Long Cay]], [[Long Island, Bahamas|Long Island]], [[Mayaguana]], [[Ragged Island, Bahamas|Ragged Island]], [[Rum Cay]], and [[San Salvador Island]].<ref name="advis5"/> Later that day, another tropical storm watch was issued for [[Abaco Islands]], [[Andros, Bahamas|Andros Island]], the [[Berry Islands]], [[Bimini]], [[Eleuthera]], [[Grand Bahama]], and [[New Providence]].<ref name="advis6"/> By early on October 24, the tropical storm watch for Cat Island, Exuma, Long Island, Rum Cay, and San Salvador was upgraded to a tropical storm warning.<ref>{{cite report|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.public.007.shtml?|title=Tropical Storm Sandy Advisory Number 7|author=John Beven II|date=October 24, 2012|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 24, 2012}}</ref>
At 1515 UTC on October 26, the Bermuda Weather Service issued a tropical storm watch for Bermuda, reflecting the enormous size of the storm and the anticipated wide-reaching impacts.<ref>{{cite report|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.update.10261513.shtml?|title=Hurricane Sandy Tropical Cyclone Update|author=Richard Pasch|date=October 26, 2012|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 26, 2012}}</ref>
===United States=== [[File:White House teleconference for Hurricane Sandy.jpg|thumb|left|[[White House]] conference with [[Federal Emergency Management Agency|FEMA]] and [[United States Department of Homeland Security|Department of Homeland Security]] in preparation for arrival of the hurricane.]]
{{wikinews|U.S. prepares for arrival of Hurricane Sandy}}
Much of the East Coast of the United States, in Mid-Atlantic and New England regions, had a good chance of receiving [[gale]]-force winds, flooding, heavy rain and possibly snow early in the week of October 28 from an unusual hybrid of Hurricane Sandy and a winter storm producing a [[Fujiwhara effect]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Forecasters warn East Coast about 'Frankenstorm' next week; damage could top $1 billion|author=Associated Press|publisher=''FoxNews.com''|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2012/10/25/trick-no-treat-forecasters-predict-pre-halloween-freak-hurricane-winter-storm/|date=October 25, 2012|accessdate=October 4, 2013}}</ref> Government weather forecasters said there was a 90% chance that the East Coast would be impacted by the storm. Jim Cisco of the [[Hydrometeorological Prediction Center]] coined the term "Frankenstorm", as Sandy was expected to merge with a storm front a few days before Halloween.<ref>{{cite news|last=Borenstein|first=Seth|title=East Coast braces for monster 'Frankenstorm'|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/east-coast-readies-frankenstorm-monster|work=Associated Press|accessdate=October 26, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Cisco |first=Jim |title=Extended Forecast Discussion – Issued 1342Z Oct 25, 2012 |url=http://www.hpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc%3Dpmdepd%26version%3D1%26fmt%3Dreg |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6BhF1xG2M?url=http://www.hpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=pmdepd&version=1&fmt=reg |dead-url=yes |archive-date=October 26, 2012 |publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center |accessdate=October 26, 2012 |date=October 25, 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Borenstein|first=Seth|title=Forecasters warn East Coast about 'Frankenstorm' next week; damage could top $1 billion|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/trick-no-treat-forecasters-predict-pre-halloween-freak-hurricane-winter-storm-mix-for-east/2012/10/25/4934cd26-1e6e-11e2-8817-41b9a7aaabc7_story.html|accessdate=October 26, 2012|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 25, 2012|agency=Associated Press}}</ref> As coverage continued, several media outlets began eschewing this term in favor of "superstorm".<ref name="foxnewssuperstorm">{{cite news|url=http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/news/2012/10/29/top-5-reasons-hurricane-sandy-is-superstorm/?intcmp=related|title=Hurricane Sandy: Five Reasons It's a Superstorm|agency=Associated Press|date=October 29, 2012|accessdate=October 29, 2012|work=Fox News}}</ref><ref name="nofrankenstorm">{{cite news|first=Patrick Kevin |last=Day |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/showtracker/la-et-st-frankenstorm-wont-be-spoken-on-cnn-20121026,0,1668678.story |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130121004640/http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/showtracker/la-et-st-frankenstorm-wont-be-spoken-on-cnn-20121026%2C0%2C1668678.story |title=No 'Frankenstorm' for CNN |date=October 26, 2012 |accessdate=October 29, 2012 |archivedate=January 21, 2013 |publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Utilities and governments along the East Coast attempted to head off long-term power failures Sandy might cause. Power companies from the Southeast to New England alerted [[independent contractor]]s to be ready to help repair storm damaged equipment quickly and asked employees to cancel vacations and work longer hours. Researchers from [[Johns Hopkins University]], using a computer model built on power outage data from previous hurricanes, conservatively forecast that 10 million customers along the Eastern Seaboard would lose power from the storm.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/capital-weather-gang/post/cause-for-concern-the-7-most-alarming-hurricane-sandy-images/2012/10/28/615bbbfe-210b-11e2-ac85-e669876c6a24_blog.html|title=Cause for concern: the 7 most alarming Hurricane Sandy images|publisher=Washington Post|accessdate=October 28, 2012|first=Jason|last=Samenow|date=October 28, 2012}}</ref>
[[File:President Obama discusses preparations for Hurricane Sandy.ogv|thumb|President Obama discusses preparations for Hurricane Sandy]]
Through regional offices in [[Atlanta]], [[Philadelphia]], [[New York City]], and [[Boston]], the [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]] (FEMA) monitored Sandy, closely coordinating with state and tribal emergency management partners in Florida and the Southeast, Mid-Atlantic, and New England states.<ref>{{cite web|last=Anderson|first=Lars|date=October 25, 2012|title=Closely Monitoring Hurricane Sandy|url=http://www.fema.gov/blog/2012-10-25/closely-monitoring-hurricane-sandy|publisher=FEMA|accessdate=October 26, 2012}}</ref> [[Barack Obama|President Obama]] signed emergency declarations on October 28 for several states expected to be impacted by Sandy, allowing them to request federal aid and make additional preparations in advance of the storm.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.blogs.cnn.com/2012/10/28/sandy-bringing-life-threatening-storm-surge|title=It's watch and wait as Hurricane Sandy approaches|publisher=News.blogs.cnn.com|accessdate=October 29, 2012|date=October 28, 2012}}</ref> Flight cancellations and travel alerts on the U.S. East Coast were put in place in the Mid-Atlantic and the New England areas.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hurricane Sandy wreaks havoc on airline flights|url=http://articles.marketwatch.com/2012-10-26/finance/34742723_1_change-fees-flight-cancellations-travel-alert|publisher=The Wall St. Journal|accessdate=October 28, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130128102129/http://articles.marketwatch.com/2012-10-26/finance/34742723_1_change-fees-flight-cancellations-travel-alert|archivedate=January 28, 2013|df=}}</ref> Over 5,000 commercial airline flights scheduled for October 28 and 29 were canceled by the afternoon of October 28<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/10/28/hurricane-sandy-flight-ca_n_2034717.html|title=Hurricane Sandy Flight Cancellations: Thousands Of Flights Canceled Due To Storm|publisher=Huffingtonpost.com|accessdate=October 29, 2012|date=October 28, 2012}}</ref> and [[Amtrak]] canceled some services through October 29 in preparation for the storm.<ref>{{cite web|title=Amtrak begins to cancel some service in advance of Hurricane Sandy|url=http://www.amtrak.com/servlet/ContentServer?c=AM_Alert_C&pagename=am/AM_Alert_C/Alerts_Popup&cid=1251622929950|publisher=Amtrak|accessdate=October 28, 2012}}</ref> In addition, the [[U.S. National Guard|National Guard]] and [[U.S. Air Force]] put as many as 45,000 personnel in at least seven states on alert for possible duty in response to the preparations and aftermath of Sandy.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hurricane Sandy Barrels Northward, May Hit New Jersey|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-10-26/widespread-power-outages-likely-as-sandy-slams-into-east.html|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=October 28, 2012|first1=Brian K|last1=Sullivan|first2=Dan|last2=Hart|date=October 28, 2012}}</ref>
====Southeast==== [[File:Sandy Oct 28 2012 1600Z.jpg|thumb|A tilted satellite image of the storm on October 28, with most of the U.S. coastline artificially highlighted. The entire east coast is visible, with a cloudless [[Florida]] coast seen at the bottom of the image and the outline of the coast of [[Maine]] at the top right.]]
=====Florida===== Schools on the [[Treasure Coast]] announced closures for October 26 in anticipation of Sandy.<ref>{{cite news|title=UPDATED: Hurricane Sandy closings and cancellations|url=http://www.cbs12.com/news/top-stories/stories/vid_2779.shtml|publisher=WPEC-TV|last1=Man|first1=Karl|last2=Smith|first2=Scott T.|last3=Wright|first3=Michele|accessdate=October 25, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121027110727/http://www.cbs12.com/news/top-stories/stories/vid_2779.shtml|archivedate=October 27, 2012|df=}}</ref> A Russian [[Signals intelligence operational platforms by nation#Russia: Ship Platforms|intelligence-gathering ship]] was allowed to stay in Jacksonville to avoid Sandy; the port is not far from [[Kings Bay Naval Submarine Base]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Russian Sub Skirts Coast |last=Gertz|first=Bill |url=http://freebeacon.com/russian-subs-skirt-coast/ |newspaper=Washington Free Beacon |publisher=Center for American Freedom |date=November 5, 2012 |accessdate=November 5, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121106002237/http://freebeacon.com/russian-subs-skirt-coast/|archivedate=November 6, 2012}}</ref>
=====Carolinas===== At 0900 UTC on October 26, a tropical storm watch was issued from the mouth of the [[Savannah River]] in [[South Carolina]] to [[Oregon Inlet]], North Carolina, including [[Pamlico Sound]].<ref>{{cite report|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.public.016.shtml?|title=Hurricane Sandy Advisory Number 16|author=Michael Brennan|date=October 26, 2012|publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=December 13, 2012}}</ref> Twelve hours later, the portion of the tropical storm watch from the [[Santee River]] in South Carolina to [[Duck, North Carolina]], including Pamlico Sound, was upgraded to a warning.<ref>{{cite report|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.public.018.shtml?|title=Hurricane Sandy Advisory Number 18|author=Richard Pasch|date=October 26, 2012|publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=December 13, 2012}}</ref> [[Governor of North Carolina]] [[Beverly Perdue]] declared a state of emergency for [[List of counties in North Carolina|38 eastern counties]] on October 26, which took effect on the following day.<ref>{{cite web|title=Perdue declares state of emergency before Sandy arrives|url=http://www.wral.com/sandy-prompts-tropical-storm-watches-along-nc-coast/11703675/|publisher=WRAL.com|accessdate=October 26, 2012}}</ref> By October 29, the state of emergency was extended to 24 counties in western North Carolina, with up to a foot (30 cm) of snow attributed to Sandy anticipated in higher elevations. The [[National Park Service]] closed at least five sections of the [[Blue Ridge Parkway]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Perdue declares state of emergency for Western NC|url=http://www.blueridgenow.com/article/20121029/ARTICLES/121029763/1008/sports?Title=Perdue-declares-state-of-emergency-for-Western-NC|publisher=WRAL.com|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref>
=====Virginia===== On October 26, [[Governor of Virginia]] [[Bob McDonnell]] declared a state of emergency. The U.S. Navy sent more than twenty-seven ships and forces to sea from [[Naval Station Norfolk]] for their protection.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> Governor McDonnell authorized the [[Virginia National Guard|National Guard]] to activate 630 personnel ahead of the storm.<ref>{{cite web|title=National Guard soldiers activated for Hurricane Sandy|url=http://www.armytimes.com/news/2012/10/ap-national-guard-activates-750-in-pa-for-sandy-102912/|publisher=Army Times|accessdate=October 31, 2012}}</ref> [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] presidential candidate [[Mitt Romney]] canceled campaign appearances scheduled for October 28 in [[Virginia Beach, Virginia]], and [[New Hampshire]] October 30 because of Sandy. Vice President [[Joe Biden]] canceled his appearance on October 27 in Virginia Beach and an October 29 campaign event in New Hampshire.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hurricane Sandy scrambles campaign schedule, Romney cancels Virginia rallies|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2012/10/27/hurricane-sandy-scrambles-campaign-schedule-romney-cancels-virginia-rallies/|publisher=Fox News|accessdate=October 28, 2012|date=October 27, 2012}}</ref> President Barack Obama canceled a campaign stop with former President [[Bill Clinton]] in Virginia scheduled for October 29, as well as a trip to [[Colorado Springs, Colorado]], the next day because of the impending storm.<ref>{{cite news|title=Obama cancels stops in Virginia, Colorado because of storm |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/travel/sns-rt-us-usa-campaign-obama-travelbre89r01a-20121027,0,6494814.story |work=Chicago Tribune |accessdate=October 28, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121030181816/http://www.chicagotribune.com/travel/sns-rt-us-usa-campaign-obama-travelbre89r01a-20121027%2C0%2C6494814.story |archivedate=October 30, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
====Mid-Atlantic====
=====Washington, D.C.===== On October 26, [[Mayor of Washington, D.C.]] [[Vincent C. Gray|Vincent Gray]] declared a state of emergency,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://mayor.dc.gov/release/district-government-prepares-hurricane-sandys-effectsuhf|title=District Government Prepares for Hurricane Sandy|date=October 26, 2012|publisher=DC.gov|accessdate=December 13, 2012}}</ref> which President Obama signed on October 28.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://washington.cbslocal.com/2012/10/28/obama-signs-d-c-emergency-declaration-due-to-sandy/|title=Pres. Obama Signs D.C. Emergency Declaration|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=October 28, 2012|newspaper=[[WUSA (TV)|CBS DC]]|accessdate=December 13, 2012}}</ref> The [[United States Office of Personnel Management]] announced federal offices in the [[Washington, D.C.]] area would be closed to the public on October 29–30.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opm.gov/status/|title=Federal Government Operating Status Washington D.C. Area|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> In addition, [[Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority|Washington D.C. Metro]] service, both rail and bus, was canceled on October 29 due to expected high winds, the likelihood of widespread power outages, and the closing of the federal government.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/metro-system-to-shut-down-on-monday/2012/10/28/2d1ee2be-2154-11e2-ac85-e669876c6a24_story.html?hpid=z2|title=Metro system to shut down on Monday|work=[[Washington Post]]|accessdate=October 28, 2012|first=Martin|last=Weil|date=October 28, 2012}}</ref> The [[Smithsonian Institution]] closed for the day of October 29.<ref name="bigstory.ap.org">{{cite news|title=A state-by-state look at the East Coast superstorm|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/state-state-look-east-coast-superstorm#overlay-context=article/report-iran-has-drone-pictures-israeli-bases|agency=AP|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref>
=====Maryland===== [[Governor of Maryland]] [[Martin O'Malley]] declared a state of emergency on October 26.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite news|title=Northeast in crosshairs of 'superstorm' Sandy|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/10/26/us/tropical-weather-sandy/index.html?hpt=hp_t1|publisher=CNN|accessdate=October 26, 2012|date=October 27, 2012}}</ref> By the following day, [[Smith Island, Maryland|Smith Island]] residents were evacuated with the assistance of the Maryland Natural Resources Police, [[Dorchester County, Maryland|Dorchester County]] opened two shelters for those in flood prone areas, and [[Ocean City, Maryland|Ocean City]] initiated Phase I of their Emergency Operations Plan.<ref>{{cite web|title=Smith Island Evacuations Under Way|url=http://www.wboc.com/story/19931873/smith-island-evacuations-under-way |publisher=WBOC|accessdate=October 27, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Dorchester County Offering Shelter During Hurricane Sandy|url=http://www.wboc.com/story/19932131/dorchester-county-offering-shelter-during-hurricane-sandy|publisher=WBOC|accessdate=October 27, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=O.C. Implementing Phase I of Emergency Operations Plan|url=http://www.wboc.com/story/19932081/oc-implementing-phase-i-of-emergency-operations-plan|publisher=WBOC|accessdate=October 27, 2012}}</ref> Baltimore Gas and Electric Co. put workers on standby and made plans to bring in crews from other states.<ref name="The Washington Examiner"/> On October 28, President Obama declared an emergency in Maryland and signed an order authorizing the Federal Emergency Management Agency to aid in disaster relief efforts.<ref>{{cite web|title=Obama Signs Maryland Emergency Declaration|url=http://www.wboc.com/story/19936125/obama-signs-md-emergency-declaration|publisher=WBOC|accessdate=October 28, 2012}}</ref> Also, numerous areas were ordered to be evacuated including part of [[Ocean City, Maryland|Ocean City]], [[Worcester County, Maryland|Worcester County]], [[Wicomico County, Maryland|Wicomico County]], and [[Somerset County, Maryland|Somerset County]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Worcester County Issues Mandatory Evacuations |url=http://www.wmdt.com/story/19936130/worcester-county-issues-mandatory-evacuations |publisher=WMDT |accessdate=October 28, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121030135141/http://www.wmdt.com/story/19936130/worcester-county-issues-mandatory-evacuations |archivedate=October 30, 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ocean City Declares Local State Of Emergency |url=http://www.wmdt.com/story/19935547/ocean-city-declares-local-state-of-emergency |publisher=WMDT |accessdate=October 28, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121030135248/http://www.wmdt.com/story/19935547/ocean-city-declares-local-state-of-emergency |archivedate=October 30, 2012 |df= }}</ref> Officials warned that more than a hundred million tons of dirty sediment mixed with tree limbs and debris floating behind [[Conowingo Dam]] could be eventually poured into the [[Chesapeake Bay]], posing a potential environmental threat.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/sandy-poses-environmental-threat-to-chesapeake-bay/2012/10/27/64bb8630-1fb2-11e2-9cd5-b55c38388962_story.html|title=Sandy poses environmental threat to Conowingo Dam|date=October 27, 2012|work=Washington Post|first=Darryl|last=Fears}}</ref>
The [[Maryland Transit Administration]] canceled all service for October 29 and 30. The cancellations applied to buses, light rail, and Amtrak and [[MARC Train|MARC]] train service.<ref>{{cite web|title=MTA Suspends Bus & Train Service On Monday; BWI Delaying & Canceling Flights Due To Hurricane Sandy|url=http://baltimore.cbslocal.com/2012/10/28/hurricane-sandy-disrupts-travel-across-md-marc-trains-canceled-for-monday|publisher=CBS News Baltimore|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> On October 29, six shelters opened in [[Baltimore]], and early voting was canceled for the day.<ref name="bigstory.ap.org"/> Maryland Insurance Commissioner Therese M. Goldsmith activated an emergency regulation requiring pharmacies to refill prescriptions regardless of their last refill date.<ref>{{cite web|title=Insurance Commissioner Issues Emergency Regulation Regarding Prescriptions, Pharmacy Payments |url=http://www.mdinsurance.state.md.us/sa/news-center/hurricane-sandy-bulletin.html |publisher=Maryland Insurance Administration |accessdate=October 28, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121029235449/http://www.mdinsurance.state.md.us/sa/news-center/hurricane-sandy-bulletin.html |archivedate=October 29, 2012 |df= }}</ref> On October 29, the [[Chesapeake Bay Bridge]] over the [[Chesapeake Bay]] and the [[Millard E. Tydings Memorial Bridge]] and [[Thomas J. Hatem Memorial Bridge]] over the [[Susquehanna River]] were closed to traffic in the midday hours.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chesapeake Bay Bridge Now Closed|url=http://www.wboc.com/story/19944902/chesapeake-bay-bridge-now-clo|publisher=WBOC TV|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref>
=====Delaware===== On October 28, Governor [[Jack Markell|Markell]] declared a state of emergency, with coastal areas of [[Sussex County, Delaware|Sussex County]] evacuated.<ref name=wboc/> In preparation for the storm, the [[Delaware Department of Transportation]] suspended some weekend construction projects, removed traffic cones and barrels from construction sites, and removed several span-wire overhead signs in Sussex County.<ref>{{cite web|title=DelDOT is preparing for a possible major storm|publisher=Delaware Department of Transportation|date=October 26, 2012|url=http://www.deldot.gov/home/newsroom/release.shtml?id=4518|accessdate=July 16, 2014}}</ref> [[Delaware Route 1]] through [[Delaware Seashore State Park]] was closed due to flooding.<ref name=wboc>{{cite web|url=http://www.wboc.com/story/19937625/sussex-county|title=Sussex County Update on Hurricane Sandy|date=October 28, 2012|publisher=[[WBOC-TV]]|accessdate=October 28, 2012}}</ref> Delaware roads were closed to the public, except for emergency and essential personnel,<ref>{{cite web|title=Delaware roads closed to public after 5 a.m|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wpvi/story?section=news/local&id=8863176|publisher=6 Action News|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> and tolls on [[Interstate 95|I-95]] and Delaware Route 1 were waived.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tolls Waived on I-95 and Route One|url=http://www.deldot.gov/home/newsroom/release.shtml?id=4522|publisher=State of Delaware|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> [[DART First State]] transit service was also suspended during the storm.<ref>{{cite web|title=DART & Paratransit Service Suspended Monday|publisher=Delaware Department of Transportation|date=October 28, 2012|url=http://www.deldot.gov/home/newsroom/release.shtml?id=4519|accessdate=July 16, 2014}}</ref>
=====New Jersey===== [[File:NJ National Guard Prepares for Hurricane Sandy.jpg|thumb|Airmen of the [[New Jersey National Guard]]'s 108th Wing assemble before being sent to assist at various emergency shelters.]] [[image:HurricaneSANDYCheltenham.jpg|thumb|A downed tree in [[Cheltenham Township, Pennsylvania]].]]
Preparations began on October 26, when officials in [[Cape May County, New Jersey|Cape May County]] advised residents on [[barrier island]]s to evacuate. There was also a voluntary evacuation for [[Mantoloking, New Jersey|Mantoloking]], [[Bay Head, New Jersey|Bay Head]], [[Barnegat Light, New Jersey|Barnegat Light]], [[Beach Haven, New Jersey|Beach Haven]], [[Harvey Cedars, New Jersey|Harvey Cedars]], [[Long Beach Township, New Jersey|Long Beach]], [[Ship Bottom, New Jersey|Ship Bottom]], and [[Stafford Township, New Jersey|Stafford]] in [[Ocean County, New Jersey|Ocean County]].<ref name="Ocean County">{{cite news|agency=Asbury Park Press|title=Ocean County towns issue voluntary evacuations|date=October 27, 2012|author=Staff|accessdate=October 27, 2012|url=http://www.app.com/article/20121026/NJNEWS/310260086/Ocean-County-towns-issue-voluntary-evacuations}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|agency=ABC7|title=Shore towns issue voluntary evac orders|date=October 26, 2012|accessdate=October 26, 2012|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=weather&id=8860237}}</ref><ref name="Bay Head">{{cite news|publisher=Point Pleasant Patch|title=Bay Head and Mantoloking Advising Voluntary Evacuations. Mantoloking police department urging residents to leave ahead of Sandy|date=October 26, 2012|author=Denise DiStephan|accessdate=October 27, 2012|url=http://pointpleasant.patch.com/articles/mantoloking-advising-voluntary-evacuations}}</ref> [[Governor of New Jersey]] [[Chris Christie]] ordered all residents of barrier islands from [[Sandy Hook]] to [[Cape May, New Jersey|Cape May]] to evacuate and closed [[Atlantic City, New Jersey|Atlantic City]] casinos. Tolls were suspended on the northbound [[Garden State Parkway]] and the westbound [[Atlantic City Expressway]] starting at 6 a.m. on October 28.<ref>{{cite news|agency=CBS2|title=Christie Declares State of Emergency; Orders Evacuations In Some Parts of N.J|date=October 27, 2012|accessdate=October 27, 2012|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2012/10/27/evacuations-begin-in-some-areas-of-new-jersey-for-hurricane-sandy/}}</ref> President Obama signed an emergency declaration for New Jersey, allowing the state to request federal funding and other assistance for actions taken before Sandy's landfall.<ref>{{cite web|title=President signs emergency declaration for NJ|url=http://www.newsday.com/news/region-state/president-signs-emergency-declaration-for-nj-1.4162619|work=Newsday|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref>
On October 28, [[Mayor of Hoboken, New Jersey|Mayor of Hoboken]] [[Dawn Zimmer]] ordered residents of basement and street-level residential units to evacuate, due to possible flooding.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hoboken mayor announces evacuation of all basements and street-level residences|url=http://www.nj.com/jjournal-news/index.ssf/2012/10/hoboken_mayor_announces_evacua.html|publisher=NewJersey.com|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> On October 29, residents of [[Logan Township, New Jersey|Logan Township]] were ordered to evacuate.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hurricane Sandy: Parts of Logan Township issued evacuation order|url=http://www.nj.com/gloucester-county/index.ssf/2012/10/portions_of_logan_township_iss.html}}</ref> [[Jersey Central Power & Light]] told employees to prepare to work extended shifts.<ref name="The Washington Examiner">{{cite web|title=Eastern utilities brace for expected super storm|url=http://washingtonexaminer.com/eastern-utilities-brace-for-expected-super-storm/article/feed/2042415#.UIofOm_WIm8|publisher=The Washington Examiner|accessdate=October 26, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131006202623/http://washingtonexaminer.com/eastern-utilities-brace-for-expected-super-storm/article/feed/2042415#.UIofOm_WIm8|archivedate=October 6, 2013|df=}}</ref> Most schools, colleges and universities were closed October 29 while at least 509 out of 580 school districts were closed October 30.<ref name=NewsWorks>{{cite web|title=Sandy makes landfall near Atlantic City; 348K N.J. homes without power|url=http://www.newsworks.org/index.php/local//item/46253-power-outages-spread-as-sandy-accelerates-toward-new-jersey-shore/|publisher=NewsWorks|accessdate=October 29, 2012|date=October 29, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130504104638/http://www.newsworks.org/index.php/local//item/46253-power-outages-spread-as-sandy-accelerates-toward-new-jersey-shore/|archivedate=May 4, 2013|df=}}</ref> Although tropical storm conditions were inevitable and hurricane-force winds were likely, the National Hurricane Center did not issue any tropical cyclone watches or warnings for New Jersey, because Sandy was forecast to become extratropical before landfall and thus would not be a tropical cyclone.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2012/11/experts_wonder_why_nhc_never_i.html|title=Experts wonder why hurricane warning was never issued for N.J. as Sandy approached|author=Stephen Stirling|date=November 1, 2012|newspaper=[[The Star-Ledger]] ([[New Jersey On-Line]])|accessdate=December 12, 2012}}</ref>
=====Pennsylvania===== Preparations in Pennsylvania began when [[Governor of Pennsylvania|Governor]] [[Tom Corbett]] declared a state of emergency on October 26.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> [[Mayor of Philadelphia]] [[Michael Nutter]] asked residents in low-lying areas and neighborhoods prone to flooding to leave their homes by 1800 UTC October 28 and move to safer ground.<ref>{{cite web|title=Philly Mayor Tells People in Flood-Prone Areas to Leave|url=http://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/news/local/Hurricane-Sandy-Philly-Mayor-urges-flood-prone-get-out-176007091.html|publisher=NBC 10 Philadelphia|accessdate=October 26, 2012}}</ref> The Philadelphia International Airport suspended all flight operations for October 29.<ref>{{cite web|title=Phila. Airport flights to be suspended Monday|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wpvi/story?section=news/local&id=8863944|publisher=6 Action News|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> On October 29, Philadelphia shut down its mass transit system.<ref name="bigstory.ap.org"/> On October 28, [[List of mayors of Harrisburg|Mayor of Harrisburg]] [[Linda D. Thompson]] declared a state of disaster emergency for the city to go into effect at 5 a.m. October 29. Electric utilities in the state brought in crews and equipment from other states such as [[New Mexico]], [[Texas]], and [[Oklahoma]], to assist with restoration efforts.<ref>{{cite web|title=Central Pennsylvania prepares for Hurricane Sandy|url=http://www.witf.org/news/2012/10/central-pennsylvania-prepares-for-hurricane-sandy.php|publisher=WITF TV|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref>
=====New York===== [[File:Sandy Poweroutage 1.jpg|thumb|left|Manhattan suffered a widespread power outage during the storm.]] [[File:Damage from Hurricane Sandy to house in Brooklyn, NY.jpeg|thumb|Damage from Hurricane Sandy to a house in [[Brooklyn|Brooklyn, New York]].]]
[[Governor of New York|Governor]] [[Andrew Cuomo]] declared a statewide state of emergency and asked for a pre-disaster declaration on October 26,<ref name="The Wall St. Journal">{{cite web|title=NYC shutting down transit, evacuating 375,000|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/cuomo-orders-nyc-transit-system-to-shut-down-2012-10-28?link=MW_latest_news|work=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> which President Obama signed later that day.<ref>{{cite web|title=Obama Signs Emergency Declaration For State Of New York|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2012/10/28/obama-signs-emergency-declaration-for-state-of-new-york/|publisher=CBS News New York|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> By October 27, major carriers canceled all flights into and out of [[John F. Kennedy International Airport|JFK]], [[LaGuardia Airport|LaGuardia]], and [[Newark Liberty International Airport|Newark-Liberty]] airports, and the [[Metro-North Railroad|Metro North]] and [[Long Island Rail Road]]s suspended service.<ref name="MyFoxNY">{{cite web|title=Hurricane Sandy forces mass transit closure, evacuations |url=http://www.myfoxny.com/story/19933026/mta-subways-ready-for-hurricane-sandy |publisher=MyFoxNY |accessdate=October 29, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121029094330/http://www.myfoxny.com/story/19933026/mta-subways-ready-for-hurricane-sandy |archivedate=October 29, 2012 |df= }}</ref> The [[Tappan Zee Bridge (1955–2017)|Tappan Zee Bridge]] was closed,<ref>{{cite web|title=3:15 p.m.: 'Tappan Zee Bridge to close at 4; 'Significant' storm surge expected to peak at midnight; Metro-North reports on tracks|url=http://www.lohud.com/viewart/20121029/NEWS02/310290065/3-05-p-m-Tappan-Zee-Bridge-to-close-at-4-Significant-storm-surge-expected-to-peak-at-midnight-Metro-North-reports-on-tracks?odyssey=tab%7Cmostpopular%7Ctext%7CFRONTPAGE|publisher=lohud.com|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> and later the [[Brooklyn Battery Tunnel]] and [[Holland Tunnel]] were also closed.<ref>{{cite news |title=Two key New York City tunnels closing; bridges open for now: governor |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/29/us-storm-sandy-tunnels-idUSBRE89S0P320121029 |publisher=Reuters |date=October 29, 2012 |accessdate=October 29, 2012 |first=Paul |last=Thomasch}}</ref> On Long Island, an evacuation was ordered for [[South Shore (Long Island)|South Shore]], including areas south of [[Sunrise Highway]], north of [[New York State Route 25A|Route 25A]], and in elevations of less than {{convert|16|ft|m}} above sea level on the [[North Shore (Long Island)|North Shore]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Nassau County calls for evacuations in coastal areas|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=weather&id=8860224|publisher=WABC TV|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> In [[Suffolk County, New York|Suffolk County]], mandatory evacuations were ordered for residents of [[Fire Island]] and six towns.<ref>{{cite web|title=Evacuations on Long Island ahead of Sandy|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=weather&id=8860224|publisher=WABC TV|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> Most schools closed in Nassau and Suffolk counties on October 29.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nassau Community, Molloy, Hofstra, Adelphi cancel classes |url=http://www.liherald.com/valleystream/stories/Nassau-Community-Hofstra-cancel-classes,44131 |publisher=Valley Stream Herald |accessdate=October 29, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131006125948/http://www.liherald.com/valleystream/stories/Nassau-Community-Hofstra-cancel-classes%2C44131 |archivedate=October 6, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
[[File:Hugh L. Carey Tunnel during Hurricane Sandy vc.jpg|thumb|The [[Brooklyn–Battery Tunnel]] remained flooded on the Tuesday morning after the storm.]]
New York City began taking precautions on October 26. Governor Cuomo ordered the closure of [[Metropolitan Transportation Authority|MTA]] and its subway on October 28, and the MTA suspended all subway, bus, and commuter rail service beginning at 2300 UTC.<ref>{{cite news|last=Mann|first=Ted|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204840504578084582421401190|title=New York City Subways to Shut Down|publisher=Online.wsj.com|accessdate=October 28, 2012|date=October 28, 2012}}</ref> After [[Effects of Hurricane Irene in New York#New York City|Hurricane Irene]] nearly submerged subways and tunnels in 2011,<ref>{{cite news |last=Navarro |first=Mireya |title=New York Is Lagging as Seas and Risks Rise, Critics Warn |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/11/nyregion/new-york-faces-rising-seas-and-slow-city-action.html?pagewanted=2&_r=0 |publisher=New York Times |accessdate=November 3, 2012 |date=September 10, 2012 |quote=Irene .. one foot short of paralyzing transportation}}</ref> entrances and grates were covered just before Sandy, but were still flooded.<ref>{{cite news|last=Caruso |first=David B. |title=Crippled NYC subways could hamper storm recovery |url=https://news.yahoo.com/crippled-nyc-subways-could-hamper-storm-recovery-213709153.html |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=November 3, 2012 |date=October 30, 2012 |work=Yahoo news}}</ref> [[Port Authority Trans-Hudson|PATH]] train service and stations as well as the [[Port Authority Bus Terminal]] were shut down in the early morning hours of October 29.<ref name="WABC TV"/><ref name="NY1 Transit"/>
Later on October 28, officials activated the coastal emergency plan, with subway closings and the evacuation of residents in areas hit by [[Hurricane Irene]] in 2011. More than 76 evacuation shelters were open around the city.<ref name="The Wall St. Journal"/> On October 29, Mayor [[Michael Bloomberg]] ordered public schools closed<ref name="WABC TV">{{cite web|title=New York City schools, transit close ahead of Sandy|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=weather&id=8860157|publisher=WABC TV|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> and called for a mandatory evacuation of Zone A, which comprised areas near coastlines or waterways.<ref>{{cite web|title=NYC Evacuation Zones: Bloomberg Orders 'Zone A' Residents to Evacuate|url=http://www.allmediany.com/news/6316-nyc-evacuation-zones-bloomberg-orders-zone-a-residents-to-evacuate|publisher=AllMediaNY|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> Additionally, 200 [[New York National Guard|National Guard]] troops were deployed in the city.<ref name="NY1 Transit">{{cite web|title=Transit Systems, Schools Plan Closings Ahead Of Sandy's Arrival |url=http://www.ny1.com/content/top_stories/171503/transit-systems--schools-plan-closings-ahead-of-sandy-s-arrival?ap=1&MP4 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130130063509/http://www.ny1.com/content/top_stories/171503/transit-systems--schools-plan-closings-ahead-of-sandy-s-arrival?ap=1&MP4 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=January 30, 2013 |publisher=NY1 |accessdate=October 29, 2012 }}</ref> [[NYU Langone Medical Center]] canceled all surgeries and medical procedures, except for emergency procedures.<ref name="NY1 Transit"/> Additionally, one of NYU Langone Medical Center's backup generators failed on October 29, prompting the evacuation of hundreds of patients, including those from the hospital's various [[intensive care units]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/superstorm-sandy-tests-hospital-preparedness/story?id=17597034#.UJEe1G_LTWo|title= Superstorm Sandy Tests Hospital Preparedness|author=Katie Moisse|author2=Sydney Lupkin|publisher=ABC News|date=October 30, 2012|accessdate=November 3, 2012}}</ref> U.S. stock trading was suspended for October 29–30.<ref>{{cite news|author=|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-505123_162-57542154/hurricane-to-keep-financial-markets-closed-tuesday|title=Sandy keeps financial markets closed Tuesday|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=October 30, 2012}}</ref>
====New England==== [[File:Flooding in Marblehead Massachusetts caused by Hurricane Sandy.jpg|thumb|left|Flooding in [[Marblehead, Massachusetts]], caused by Hurricane Sandy on October 29.]]
Connecticut Governor [[Dannel Malloy]] partially activated the state's Emergency Operations Center on October 26<ref name="CT.gov">{{cite web|title=Governor Malloy to Partially Activate the State Emergency Operations Center at 8am Saturday|url=http://www.governor.ct.gov/malloy/cwp/view.asp?A=4010&Q=513076|work=Hurricane Sandy News and Information|publisher=CT.gov|accessdate=October 27, 2012}}</ref> and signed a Declaration of Emergency the next day.<ref name="governor.ct.gov">{{cite web|title=Gov. Malloy Signs Declaration of Emergency|url=http://www.governor.ct.gov/malloy/cwp/view.asp?Q=513088&A=4010|work=Hurricane Sandy News and Information|publisher=CT.gov|accessdate=October 27, 2012}}</ref> On October 28, President Obama approved Connecticut's request for an emergency declaration, and hundreds of [[Connecticut National Guard|National Guard]] personnel were deployed.<ref name="thehour.com">{{cite web|title=Obama approves pre-landfall emergency declaration for Connecticut|url=http://www.thehour.com/news/state/obama-approves-pre-landfall-emergency-declaration-for-connecticut/article_a5384ada-2175-11e2-8370-0019bb30f31a.html|work=The Hour|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> On October 29, Governor Malloy ordered road closures for all state highways.<ref>{{cite web|title=All Connecticut highways closed as Sandy approaches|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=weather&id=8861658|publisher=WABC TV|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> Numerous mandatory and partial evacuations were issued in cities across Connecticut.<ref name="ctnowevac">{{cite web|url=http://www.ctnow.com/weather/hurricane/hc-townbytown-evacuations-20121028,0,1651268.story|title=Town-By-Town Evacuations|date=October 28, 2012|accessdate=October 29, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121030211934/http://www.ctnow.com/weather/hurricane/hc-townbytown-evacuations-20121028,0,1651268.story|archivedate=October 30, 2012|df=}}</ref>
Massachusetts Governor [[Deval Patrick]] ordered state offices to be closed October 29 and recommended schools and private businesses close. On October 28, President Obama issued a Pre-Landfall Emergency Declaration for Massachusetts. Several shelters were opened, and many schools were closed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mass. Braces For Hurricane Sandy|url=http://www.wbur.org/2012/10/28/sandy-mass3|publisher=WBUR Radio|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> The [[Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority]] shut down all services on the afternoon of October 29.<ref>{{cite news|title=Boston's MBTA to shut down at 2 pm|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/2012/10/29/boston-mbta-shut-down/u0FHc2jxvujsLu0L92rdqJ/story.html|publisher=Boston.com|accessdate=October 29, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121101025314/http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/2012/10/29/boston-mbta-shut-down/u0FHc2jxvujsLu0L92rdqJ/story.html|archive-date=November 1, 2012}}</ref> On October 28, Vermont Governor [[Peter Shumlin]], New Hampshire Governor [[John Lynch (New Hampshire)|John Lynch]], and [[Maine]]'s Governor [[Paul LePage]] all declared states of emergency.<ref name="bigstory.ap.org"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Goswami|first=Neal|title=Vt. in state of emergency ahead of Sandy|url=http://www.benningtonbanner.com/news/ci_21877376/vt-state-emergency-ahead-sandy|work=The Bennington Banner|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Edwards|first=Holly|title=Gov. LePage signs emergency declaration ahead of Sandy|url=http://www.penbaypilot.com/article/gov-lepage-signs-emergency-declaration-ahead-sandy/4958|publisher=penbaypilot.com|accessdate=October 27, 2012}}</ref>
====Appalachia and the Midwest==== The National Weather Service issued a storm warning for [[Lake Huron]] on October 29 that called for wave heights of {{convert|26|ft|m}}, and possibly as high as {{convert|38|ft|m}}. [[Lake Michigan]] waves were expected to reach {{convert|19|ft|m}}, with a potential of {{convert|33|ft|m}} on October 30.<ref name=Michigan/> Flood warnings were issued in [[Chicago]] on October 29, where wave heights were expected to reach {{convert|18|to|23|ft|m}} in [[Cook County, Illinois|Cook County]] and {{convert|25|ft|m}} in northwest [[Indiana]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Sandy's Winds And Rain Cause Flood Warnings, Flight And Train Cancellations|url=http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2012/10/29/sandys-winds-and-rain-cause-flood-warnings-flight-and-train-cancellations/|publisher=CBS News Chicago|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> Gale warnings were issued for Lake Michigan and [[Green Bay (Lake Michigan)|Green Bay]] in Wisconsin until the morning of October 31, and waves of {{convert|33|ft|m}} in [[Milwaukee]] and {{convert|20|ft|m}} in [[Sheboygan, Wisconsin|Sheboygan]] were predicted for October 30.<ref name=GBPG/> The actual waves reached about {{convert|20|ft|m}} but were less damaging than expected.<ref>{{cite news|last=Robbins|first=John|title=Superstorm waves cause little damage along Lake Michigan shoreline|url=http://posttrib.suntimes.com/news/lake/16086637-418/superstorm-waves-cause-little-damage-along-lake-michigan-shoreline.html|newspaper=Post-Tribune|date=November 1, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105033715/http://posttrib.suntimes.com/news/lake/16086637-418/superstorm-waves-cause-little-damage-along-lake-michigan-shoreline.html|archivedate=November 5, 2012|df=}}</ref><ref name=postcrescent>{{cite news|last=Srubas|first=Paul|title=Wisconsin gets a taste of Sandy's fury|url=http://www.postcrescent.com/article/20121031/APC0101/310310417/Wisconsin-gets-taste-Sandy-s-fury-story-photos-video-?nclick_check=1|newspaper=Post-Crescent|date=Oct 31, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140824124940/http://www.postcrescent.com/article/20121031/APC0101/310310417/Wisconsin-gets-taste-Sandy-s-fury-story-photos-video-?nclick_check=1|archivedate=August 24, 2014|df=}}</ref> The village of [[Pleasant Prairie, Wisconsin]] urged a voluntary evacuation of its lakefront area, though few residents signed up, and little flooding actually occurred.<ref name=GBPG>{{cite news|url=http://www.greenbaypressgazette.com/article/20121030/GPG0101/310300254/Sandy-s-reach-spreads-Wisconsin|title= Sandy's reach spreads to Wisconsin|newspaper=Green Bay Press Gazette|date=October 30, 2012|accessdate=October 30, 2012|first=Paul|last=Srubas}}</ref><ref name=postcrescent/>
