===Caribbean=== {{main|Effects of Hurricane Sandy in the Greater Antilles}}
====Jamaica==== Jamaica was the first country directly affected by Sandy, which was also the first hurricane to make landfall on the island since [[Hurricane Gilbert]], [[1988 Atlantic hurricane season|24 years prior]]. Trees and power lines were snapped and shanty houses were heavily damaged, both from the winds and flooding rains. More than 100 fishermen were stranded in outlying [[Pedro Cays]] off Jamaica's southern coast.<ref>{{cite news|title=Weakened hurricane lashes Bahamas after 21 deaths|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/tropical-storm-tony-develops-far-out-atlantic|work=Associated Press|accessdate=October 25, 2012}}</ref> Stones falling from a hillside crushed one man to death as he tried to get into his house in a rural village near Kingston.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hurricane Sandy Hits Cuba after Jamaica |url=http://news.sky.com/story/1002376/hurricane-sandy-brings-heavy-flooding-to-jamaica |publisher=Sky News |date=October 25, 2012 |accessdate=October 25, 2012}}</ref> After 6 days another fatality recorded as a 27-year-old man, died due to electrocution, attempting a repair.<ref name="Diakakis et al 2013"/> The country's sole electricity provider, the Jamaica Public Service Company, reported that 70 percent of its customers were without power. More than 1,000 people went to shelters. Jamaican authorities closed the island's international airports, and police ordered 48-hour curfews in major towns to keep people off the streets and deter looting.<ref>{{cite news |title=Hurricane Sandy pounds Jamaica, heads toward Cuba |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/25/us-storm-sandy-hurricane-idUSBRE89N16J20121025 |publisher=Reuters|accessdate=October 25, 2012 |date=October 25, 2012}}</ref> Most buildings in the eastern portion of the island lost their roofs.<ref name="autogenerated2"/> Damage was assessed at approximately $100 million throughout the country.<ref name="SandyTCR"/>
====Hispaniola==== In Haiti, which was still recovering from both the [[2010 Haiti earthquake|2010 earthquake]] and the ongoing [[2010–2011 Haiti cholera outbreak|cholera outbreak]], at least 54 people died,<ref name="WAVY deaths"/> and approximately 200,000 were left homeless as a result of four days of ongoing rain from Hurricane Sandy.<ref name="charles1">{{cite web|last=Charles and Morgan|first=Jacqueline and Curtis|title=Sandy's death toll climbs to 44 in Haiti|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2012/10/27/3069750/sandy-still-a-hurricane-heads.html|work=The Miami Herald|accessdate=October 28, 2012}}</ref> Heavy damage occurred in [[Port-Salut]] after rivers overflowed their banks.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hurricane Sandy pounds Jamaica, eyes U.S|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-202_162-57539172/hurricane-sandy-pounds-jamaica-haiti-eyes-u.s/|publisher=CBS|accessdate=October 24, 2012}}</ref> In the capital of [[Port-au-Prince]], streets were flooded by the heavy rains, and it was reported that "the whole south of the country is underwater".<ref>{{cite web|title=65 dead as Hurricane Sandy crosses Caribbean; 'the whole south is under water,' says Haitian PM (with video) |url=https://ottawacitizen.com/news/Hurricane+Sandys+death+toll+rises+flooding+continues+Haiti/7460465/story.html |publisher=Ottawa Citizen |accessdate=October 29, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103084337/http://www.ottawacitizen.com/news/Hurricane%2BSandys%2Bdeath%2Btoll%2Brises%2Bflooding%2Bcontinues%2BHaiti/7460465/story.html |archivedate=November 3, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Most of the tents and buildings in the city's sprawling refugee camps and the [[Cité Soleil]] neighborhood were flooded or leaking, a repeat of what happened earlier in the year during the passage of [[Hurricane Isaac (2012)|Hurricane Isaac]].<ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite web|title=Soggy Jamaica cleaning up after Hurricane Sandy |url=http://www.adn.com/2012/10/25/2672037/soggy-jamaica-cleaning-up-after.html |work=Anchorage Daily News |accessdate=October 25, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103051909/http://www.adn.com/2012/10/25/2672037/soggy-jamaica-cleaning-up-after.html |archivedate=November 3, 2012 |df= }}</ref> Crops were also wiped out by the storm and the country would be making an appeal for emergency aid.<ref>{{cite web|title=Food Crisis, Cholera Feared in Haiti|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/cheats/2012/10/30/food-crisis-cholera-feared-in-haiti.html|publisher=The Daily Beast|accessdate=October 30, 2012}}</ref> Damage in Haiti was estimated at $750 million (2012 USD), making it the costliest tropical cyclone in Haitian history.<ref name="SacBee"/> In the month following Sandy, a resurgence of [[cholera]] linked to the storm killed at least 44 people and infected more than 5,000 others.<ref name="HaitiCholera">{{cite web|work=Agence France-Presse|publisher=ReliefWeb|date=November 20, 2012|accessdate=November 21, 2012|title=Haïti : 44 décès en un mois, le choléra en hausse après Sandy|url=http://reliefweb.int/report/haiti/ha%C3%AFti-44-d%C3%A9c%C3%A8s-en-un-mois-le-chol%C3%A9ra-en-hausse-apr%C3%A8s-sandy|language=es}}</ref>
In the neighboring [[Dominican Republic]], two people were killed and 30,000 people evacuated.<ref name="WP Deaths"/> An employee of [[CNN]] estimated 70% of the streets in [[Santo Domingo]] were flooded.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Castillo|first1=Mariano |last2=Almasy |first2=Steve|title=Sandy kills 11 in Cuba, then batters Bahamas|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/10/25/world/americas/tropical-weather-sandy/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=October 26, 2012|date=October 26, 2012}}</ref> One person was killed in [[Juana Díaz, Puerto Rico]] after being swept away by a swollen river.<ref name="WP Deaths"/>
====Cuba==== {{Costliest Cuban hurricanes}} [[File:Flickr - DVIDSHUB - Hurricane Sandy hits Guantanamo Bay (Image 1 of 3).jpg|thumbnail|left|Hurricane Sandy damage in Guantanamo Bay]] At least 55,000 people were evacuated before Hurricane Sandy's arrival.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hurricane Sandy growing stronger as it nears Cuba|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/sns-rt-us-storm-sandy-hurricanebre89n16j-20121024,0,600093.story|work=The Chicago Tribune|accessdate=October 25, 2012|first1=Jeanine|last1=Prezioso|first2=Jonathan|last2=Allen}}</ref> While moving ashore, the storm produced waves up to 29 feet (9 meters) and a 6-foot (2 meter) storm surge that caused extensive coastal flooding.<ref>{{cite news|title=Strengthening Hurricane Sandy slams into Cuba|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/25/us-storm-sandy-hurricane-idUSBRE89N16J20121025|agency=Reuters|accessdate=October 25, 2012|date=October 25, 2012}}</ref> There was widespread damage, particularly to Santiago de Cuba where 132,733 homes were damaged, of which 15,322 were destroyed and 43,426 lost their roof.<ref name="CubaDamage"/> Electricity and water services were knocked out, and most of the trees in the city were damaged. Total losses throughout Santiago de Cuba province is estimated as high as $2 billion (2012 USD).<ref name="HavanaTimes"/> Sandy killed 11 people in the country – nine in [[Santiago de Cuba Province]] and two in [[Guantánamo Province]]; most of the victims were trapped in destroyed houses.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cuban state media say 11 deaths in Hurricane Sandy|url=http://www.ajc.com/ap/ap/top-news/cuban-state-media-say-11-deaths-in-hurricane-sandy/nSn3m/|work=[[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]|accessdate=October 26, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Hurricane Sandy leaves trail of destruction in Cuba|url=http://www.trust.org/alertnet/news/hurricane-sandy-leaves-trail-of-destruction-in-cuba|publisher=Trust.org|accessdate=October 26, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130416044828/http://www.trust.org/alertnet/news/hurricane-sandy-leaves-trail-of-destruction-in-cuba|archivedate=April 16, 2013|df=}}</ref> This makes Sandy the deadliest hurricane to hit Cuba since 2005, when [[Hurricane Dennis]] killed 16 people.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hurricane Sandy rages through Bahamas, after killing 29 in the Caribbean, en route to US coast|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/hurricane-sandy-whips-at-bahamas-with-wind-and-rain-will-soon-threaten-us-east-coast/2012/10/25/e63d698a-1f08-11e2-8817-41b9a7aaabc7_story.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103065840/http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/hurricane-sandy-whips-at-bahamas-with-wind-and-rain-will-soon-threaten-us-east-coast/2012/10/25/e63d698a-1f08-11e2-8817-41b9a7aaabc7_story.html|archive-date=November 3, 2012|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=October 26, 2012|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
====Bahamas==== A [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]] automated station at [[West End, Grand Bahama|Settlement Point]] on [[Grand Bahama Island]] reported sustained winds of 49 mph (74 km/h) and a wind gust of 63 mph (102 km/h).<ref>{{cite report|author=Richard Pasch|title=Hurricane Sandy Advisory Number 18|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2012/al18/al182012.public.018.shtml?|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 26, 2012}}</ref> One person died from falling off his roof while attempting to fix a window shutter in the Lyford Cay area on New Providence. Another died in the Queen's Cove area on Grand Bahama Island where he drowned after the sea surge trapped him in his apartment.<ref name="WP Deaths"/> Portions of the Bahamas lost power or cellular service, including an islandwide power outage on [[Bimini]]. Five homes were severely damaged near Williams's Town.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Tribune (Nassau)|date=October 27, 2012|title=Btc Post Hurricane Update|accessdate=October 28, 2012|url=http://www.tribune242.com/news/2012/oct/27/btc-post-hurricane-update/}}</ref> Overall damage in the Bahamas was about $700 million (2012 USD), with the most severe damage on [[Cat Island (Bahamas)|Cat Island]] and [[Exuma]] where many houses were heavily damaged by wind and storm surge.<ref name="Tribune242"/>
===Bermuda=== Owing to the sheer size of the storm, Sandy also impacted Bermuda with high winds and heavy rains. On October 28, a weak [[Fujita Scale|F0]] tornado touched down in [[Sandys Parish]], damaging homes and businesses.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Bermuda Weather|date=October 28, 2012|accessdate=October 31, 2012|title=Hurricane Sandy Spawns a tornado in Bermuda|url=http://bermudaweather.wordpress.com/2012/10/28/hurricane-sandy-spawns-a-tornado-in-bermuda/}}</ref> During a three-day span, the storm produced {{convert|0.98|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain at the [[L.F. Wade International Airport]]. The strongest winds were recorded on October 29: sustained winds reached {{convert|37|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} and gusts peaked at {{convert|58|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, which produced scattered minor damage.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Bermuda Weather Service |date=October 2012 |accessdate=October 31, 2012 |title=Daily Climatology Written Summary: October 1, 2012 to October 30, 2012 |url=http://www.weather.bm/climate.asp |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091216052441/http://www.weather.bm/climate.asp |archivedate=December 16, 2009 |df= }}</ref>
===United States=== {{Costliest U.S. Atlantic hurricanes}} [[File:Hurricane Sandy New Jersey Pier.jpg|thumb|left|Damage to [[Casino Pier]] in [[Seaside Heights, New Jersey|Seaside Heights]], New Jersey]] A total of 24 [[U.S. state]]s were in some way affected by Sandy. The hurricane caused tens of billions of dollars in damage in the United States, destroyed thousands of homes, left millions without electric service,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/weather/2012/10/29/hurricane-sandy-east-coast-frankenstorm/1666105/|title=Sandy leaves millions without power; 16 dead|date=October 30, 2012|accessdate=November 5, 2012|work=USA Today|first1=Kevin|last1=McCoy|first2=Elizabeth|last2=Weise}}</ref> and caused 71 direct deaths in nine states, including 49 in New York, 10 in New Jersey, 3 in Connecticut, 2 each in Pennsylvania and Maryland, and 1 each in New Hampshire, Virginia and West Virginia.<ref name="Diakakis et al 2013"/> There were also 2 direct deaths from Sandy in U.S. coastal waters in the Atlantic Ocean, about 90 miles (150 km) off the North Carolina coast, which are not counted in the U.S. total. In addition, the storm resulted in 87 indirect deaths.<ref name="SandyTCR"/> In all, a total of 160 people were killed due to the storm, making Sandy the deadliest hurricane to hit the United States mainland since [[Hurricane Katrina]] in 2005 and the deadliest to hit the [[East Coast of the United States|U.S. East Coast]] since [[Hurricane Agnes]] in 1972.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/usdeadly.asp |title=Deadliest U.S. Hurricanes of All Time | Weather Underground |publisher=Wunderground.com |date=April 27, 2012 |accessdate=February 9, 2013}}</ref>
Due to flooding and other storm-related problems, [[Amtrak]] canceled all [[Acela Express]], [[Northeast Regional]], [[Keystone Service|Keystone]], and Shuttle services for October 29 and 30.<ref>{{cite web|title=Amtrak Northeast Corridor Services Canceled on Monday, October 29|url=http://www.amtrak.com/servlet/ContentServer?c=AM_Alert_C&pagename=am/AM_Alert_C/Alerts_Popup&cid=1251622931902|date=October 28, 2012|publisher=[[Amtrak]]|accessdate=October 30, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Most Amtrak Service in the Northeast remains Suspended on Tuesday, October 30|url=http://www.amtrak.com/servlet/ContentServer?c=AM_Alert_C&pagename=am/AM_Alert_C/Alerts_Popup&cid=1251622933972|date=October 29, 2012|publisher=Amtrak|accessdate=October 30, 2012}}</ref> More than 13,000 flights were canceled across the U.S. on October 29, and more than 3,500 were called off October 30.<ref name="msnbc">{{cite web|title=Catastrophic flooding hits Northeast as Sandy plows ashore|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/49593609/ns/weather|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=October 30, 2012}}</ref> From October 27 through early November 1, airlines canceled a total of 19,729 flights, according to [[FlightAware]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Sandy: Flight cancellations push 20,000, but start to ease|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/todayinthesky/2012/11/01/airline-cancellation-tally/1673823/|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=November 1, 2012|first1=Ben|last1=Mutzabaugh|date=November 1, 2012}}</ref>
On October 31, over 6 million customers were still without power in 15 states and the [[District of Columbia]]. The states with the most customers without power were [[New Jersey]] with 2,040,195 customers; [[New York (state)|New York]] with 1,933,147; [[Pennsylvania]] with 852,458; and [[Connecticut]] with 486,927.<ref name="SandySitRpt6">{{cite web|title=Hurricane Sandy Situation Report #6|publisher=United States Department of Energy Office of Electricity Delivery & Energy Reliability|date=October 31, 2012|accessdate=March 7, 2013|url=http://www.oe.netl.doe.gov/docs/2012_SitRep6_Sandy_10312012_1000AM_v_1.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> [[File:Sandy 2012 rainfall.gif|thumb|left|upright|Storm total rainfall for Sandy (2012) across the United States]] The [[New York Stock Exchange]] and [[Nasdaq]] reopened on October 31 after a two-day closure for the storm.<ref name="ABC News">{{cite web|title=Superstorm Sandy: 33 Dead and 8 Million Customers Without Power|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/superstorm-sandy-33-dead-estimated-million-power/story?id=17594562#.UJAFFG_WIm8|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=October 30, 2012}}</ref> More than 1,500 FEMA personnel were along the East Coast working to support disaster preparedness and response operations, including search and rescue, situational awareness, communications and logistical support. In addition, 28 teams containing 294 FEMA Corps members were pre-staged to support Sandy responders. Three federal urban search and rescue task forces were positioned in the Mid-Atlantic and ready to deploy as needed.<ref name="ens-newswire">{{cite web|title=Vicious Superstorm Sandy Smashes U.S. Northeast Cities|url=http://ens-newswire.com/2012/10/29/vicious-superstorm-sandy-smashes-u-s-northeast-cities/|publisher=newswire.com|accessdate=October 30, 2012}}</ref>
On November 2, the [[American Red Cross]] announced they had 4,000 disaster workers across storm damaged areas, with thousands more ''en route'' from other states. Nearly 7,000 people spent the night in emergency shelters across the region.<ref>{{cite news|title=Storm Aftermath: Live Updates|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2012/10/28/nyregion/hurricane-sandy.html?smid=tw-nytimes#sha=c5d4b7366|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=November 2, 2012|date=October 28, 2012}}</ref>
''[[Hurricane Sandy: Coming Together]]'', a live telethon on November 2 that featured rock and pop stars such as [[Bruce Springsteen]], [[Billy Joel]], [[Jon Bon Jovi]], [[Mary J. Blige]], [[Sting (musician)|Sting]] and [[Christina Aguilera]], raised around $23 million for [[American Red Cross]] hurricane relief efforts.<ref>{{cite web|title=Concert to Help Hurricane Sandy Victims Raises $23 Mln|url=http://en.ria.ru/world/20121104/177184665.html|publisher=RIA NOVOSTI WEBSITE GROUP|accessdate=November 4, 2012}}</ref>
As of November 5, 2012, the [[National Hurricane Center]] ranks Hurricane Sandy the second-costliest US hurricane since 1900 in constant 2010 dollars, and the sixth-costliest after adjusting for [[inflation]], population and property values.<ref name=NHCStormCost>{{cite news|title=Is Sandy the second-most destructive U.S. hurricane ever? Or not even top 10?|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/ezra-klein/wp/2012/11/05/is-sandy-the-second-most-destructive-u-s-hurricane-ever-or-not-even-top-10/#comments|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=November 5, 2012}}</ref> Their report also states that due to global warming the number of future hurricanes will "either decrease or remain essentially unchanged" overall, but the ones that do form will likely be stronger, with fiercer winds and heavier rains.<ref name=NHCStormCost />
Scientists at the [[University of Utah]] reported the energy generated by Sandy was equivalent to "small earthquakes between magnitudes 2 and 3".<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Superstorm-Sandy-jolted-United-States/tabid/1160/articleID/294877/Default.aspx|work=3 News NZ |title= Superstorm Sandy jolted United States| date=April 19, 2013}}</ref>
====Southeast====
=====Florida===== In South Florida, Sandy lashed the area with rough surf, strong winds, and brief squalls. Along the coast of [[Miami-Dade County, Florida|Miami-Dade County]], waves reached {{convert|10|ft|m}}, but may have been as high as {{convert|20|ft|m}} in [[Palm Beach County, Florida|Palm Beach County]]. In the former county, minor pounding occurred on a few coastal roads. Further north in [[Broward County, Florida|Broward County]], [[Florida State Road A1A|State Road A1A]] was inundated with sand and water, causing more than a {{convert|2|mi|km}} stretch of the road to be closed for the entire weekend. Additionally, coastal flooding extended inland up to 2 blocks in some locations and a few houses in the area suffered water damage. In [[Manalapan, Florida|Manalapan]], which is located in southern Palm Beach County, several beachfront homes were threatened by erosion. The [[Lake Worth, Florida|Lake Worth]] Pier was also damaged by rough seas. In Palm Beach County alone, losses reached $14 million.<ref name="nwsmiami">{{cite web|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/mfl/?n=sandy|title=Hurricane Sandy Overview|date=November 30, 2012|publisher=[[National Weather Service Miami, Florida]]|accessdate=December 12, 2012}}</ref> Sandy caused closures and cancellations of some activities at schools in [[Palm Beach County, Florida|Palm Beach]], [[Broward County, Florida|Broward]] and [[Miami-Dade County, Florida|Miami-Dade]] counties.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2012/10/25/3066926/hurricane-sandy-cancels-school.html|title=Hurricane Sandy forces cancellation of school athletic events in South Florida|last=Veiga|first=Christina Veiga|newspaper=[[Miami Herald]]|date=October 25, 2012|accessdate=October 30, 2012}}</ref> Storm surge from Sandy also caused flooding and beach erosion along coastal areas in South Florida.<ref>[http://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/palm-beach/fl-high-tides-infrastructure-20121029,0,6541118.story Ocean's wrath floods neighborhoods, rips up beaches] by David Fleshler and Robert Nolin, ''[[South Florida Sun-Sentinel]]''. Published October 28, 2012; retrieved 2012-10-30.</ref> Gusty winds also impacted South Florida, peaking at {{convert|67|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} in [[Jupiter, Florida|Jupiter]] and [[Fowey Rocks Light]], which is near [[Key Biscayne]].<ref name="nwsmiami"/> The storm left power outages across the region, which left many traffic lights out of order.<ref>{{cite news|agency=WSVN-TV|date=October 26, 2012|title=South Florida cleans up after Sandy|accessdate=October 26, 2012|url=http://www.wsvn.com/news/articles/tracking_tropics/21008896703574/south-florida-cleans-up-after-sandy/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121029035612/http://www.wsvn.com/news/articles/tracking_tropics/21008896703574/south-florida-cleans-up-after-sandy|archive-date=October 29, 2012}}</ref>
In east-central Florida, damage was minor, though the storm left about 1,000 people without power.<ref name="Orlando">{{cite news|agency=Click Orlando|date=October 26, 2012|title=Hurricane Sandy brings rain, strong winds to Central Florida|accessdate=October 26, 2012|url=http://www.clickorlando.com/weather/Hurricane-Sandy-brings-rain-strong-winds-to-Central-Florida/-/1636950/17141130/-/43onqhz/-/index.html}}</ref> Airlines at [[Miami International Airport]] canceled more than 20 flights to or from [[Jamaica]] or [[the Bahamas]], while some airlines flying from [[Fort Lauderdale–Hollywood International Airport]] canceled a total of 13 flights to the islands.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> The [[Coast Guard]] rescued two sea men in [[Volusia County]] off [[New Smyrna Beach]] on the morning of October 26.<ref>{{cite web|title=2 boaters rescued near New Smyrna Beach|url=http://www.cfnews13.com/content/news/cfnews13/news/article.html/content/news/articles/cfn/2012/10/26/_2_boaters_rescued_n.html|work=Central Florida News 13|accessdate=October 27, 2012}}</ref> [[Brevard County|Brevard]] and Volusia Counties schools canceled all extracurricular activities for October 26, including football.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hurricane Sandy cancels and postpones Brevard and Volusia County football on October 26. games|url=http://www.cfnews13.com/content/news/cfnews13/sports/article.html/content/news/articles/bhsn/2012/10/25/hurricane_sandy_canc.html|publisher=CFN13|accessdate=October 27, 2012}}</ref>
Two [[Florida panther|panther]] kittens escaped from the White Oak Conservation Center in Nassau County after the hurricane swept a tree into the fence of their enclosure; they were missing for 24 hours before being found in good health.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sandy sets panthers free in Florida after falling tree destroys enclosure|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2226754/Hurricane-Sandy-sets-panthers-free-Florida-falling-tree-destroys-enclosure.html|publisher=Daily Mail|accessdate=November 2, 2012|first=Eddie|last=Wrenn|location=London|date=November 2, 2012}}</ref>
=====North Carolina===== [[File:121029-G-ZZ999-002 - Coast Guard rescues crewmembers aboard HMS.jpg|thumb|The 180-foot (55 m) sailing ship, ''[[Bounty (1960 ship)|Bounty]]'', is shown nearly submerged during Hurricane Sandy in the Atlantic Ocean approximately {{convert|90|mi}} southeast of Hatteras, North Carolina on Monday, October 29, 2012.]]
On October 28, Governor [[Bev Perdue]] declared a state of emergency in 24 western counties, due to snow and strong winds.<ref>{{cite web|title=Gov. Perdue Declares State of Emergency for 24 Western Counties|url=http://www.governor.state.nc.us/NewsItems/PressReleaseDetail.aspx?newsItemID=2648|publisher=State of NC|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref>
[[North Carolina]] was spared from major damage for the most part (except at the immediate coastline), though winds, rain, and mountain snow affected the state through October 30. [[Ocracoke, North Carolina|Ocracoke]] and [[North Carolina Highway 12|Highway 12]] on [[Hatteras Island]] were flooded with up to {{convert|2|ft|m|sigfig=1}} of water, closing part of the highway, while 20 people on a fishing trip were stranded on [[Portsmouth Island]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wral.com/soundside-flooding-possible-as-sandy-trudges-along-outer-banks/11710690/|title=Hatteras, Ocracoke get worst of Hurricane Sandy in NC|publisher=wral.com|accessdate=October 28, 2012}}</ref>
There were three Hurricane Sandy-related deaths in the state.<ref name="Diakakis et al 2013"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Hurricane Sandy: CT, NY, NJ And Other East Coast States Assess Region After Deadly Storm|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/11/03/hurricane-sandy-ct-ny-nj-death-storm_n_2070096.html|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=November 4, 2012|date=November 3, 2012}}</ref>
On October 29, the [[United States Coast Guard|Coast Guard]] responded to a distress call from ''[[Bounty (1960 ship)|Bounty]]'', which was built for the 1962 movie ''[[Mutiny on the Bounty (1962 film)|Mutiny on the Bounty]]''. It was taking on water about 90 miles (150 km) southeast of [[Cape Hatteras]]. Sixteen people were on board.<ref>{{cite news |title=Coast Guard Monitors Tall Ship in Distress off NC|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/coast-guard-monitors-tall-ship-distress-off-nc-17586778#.UI5Dfm_WIm8|work=ABC News|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> The Coast Guard said the 16 people abandoned ship and got into two lifeboats, wearing survival suits and life jackets.<ref>{{cite news |title=Crew of tall ship off NC abandons ship |url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_SUPERSTORM_SHIP?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT |agency=The Associated Press |accessdate=October 29, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121029114717/http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_SUPERSTORM_SHIP?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT |archivedate=October 29, 2012 |df= }}</ref> The ship sank after the crew got off.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hurricane Sandy sinks tall ship HMS Bounty|url=https://news.yahoo.com/hurricane-sandy-forces-hms-bounty-evacuation-094802868.html |work=Yahoo News|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> The Coast Guard rescued 14 crew members; another was found hours later but was unresponsive and later died.<ref name="bigstory">{{cite news|title=SUPERSTORM SANDY SLAMS INTO NEW JERSEY COAST |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/superstorm-sandy-takes-aim-atlantic-coast-0 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121030211337/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/superstorm-sandy-takes-aim-atlantic-coast-0 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=October 30, 2012 |work=Associated Press |accessdate=October 30, 2012 }}</ref> The search for the captain, Robin Walbridge, was suspended on November 1, after efforts lasting more than 90 hours and covering approximately 12,000 [[square nautical miles]] (41,100 km²).<ref name=washingtonpostbountysearchended>{{cite news|title=Search halted for missing ship captain after 3 days scouring sea off NC; ship sank in Sandy|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/search-off-north-carolina-coast-for-missing-tall-ship-captain-enters-its-4th-day/2012/11/01/4af4b1be-241b-11e2-92f8-7f9c4daf276a_story.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121102172017/http://www.washingtonpost.com/national/search-off-north-carolina-coast-for-missing-tall-ship-captain-enters-its-4th-day/2012/11/01/4af4b1be-241b-11e2-92f8-7f9c4daf276a_story.html|archive-date=November 2, 2012|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=November 2, 2012|date=November 1, 2012|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
=====Virginia===== [[File:Hurricane Sandy hit Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge (VA) (8141816490).jpg|thumb|Damaged road at [[Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge]] on [[Assateague Island]]]] On October 29, snow was falling in parts of the state.<ref name="washingtonpost1"/> Gov. [[Bob McDonnell]] announced on October 30 that Virginia had been "spared a significant event", but cited concerns about rivers cresting and consequent flooding of major arteries. Virginia was awarded a federal disaster declaration, with Gov. McDonnell saying he was "delighted" that President Barack Obama and FEMA were on it immediately. At Sandy's peak, more than 180,000 customers were without power, most of whom were located in [[Northern Virginia]].<ref name="SandySitRpt6"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://annandale.patch.com/articles/gov-mcdonnell-virginia-spared-in-hurricane-sandy-damage|title=Gov. McDonnell: Virginia 'Spared' in Hurricane Sandy Damage|publisher=Annandale Patch|accessdate=October 30, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130131230258/http://annandale.patch.com/articles/gov-mcdonnell-virginia-spared-in-hurricane-sandy-damage|archivedate=January 31, 2013|df=}}</ref> There were three Hurricane Sandy-related fatalities in the state.<ref name="Diakakis et al 2013"/><ref name="usnews.nbcnews" />
====Mid-Atlantic====
=====Maryland and Washington, D.C.===== {{main|Effects of Hurricane Sandy in Maryland and Washington, D.C.}} [[File:Hurricane Sandy flooding Crisfield MD.jpg|thumb|left|Flooding in [[Crisfield, Maryland]]]] The [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] and the [[United States Government]] [[Office of Personnel Management]] were closed on October 30,<ref>{{cite news|title=Supreme Court won't convene on Tuesday due to storm: spokeswoman|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/29/us-usa-court-meeting-idUSBRE89S0QJ20121029|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=October 29, 2012|date=October 29, 2012|first=Joan|last=Biskupic}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opm.gov/status/index.aspx|title=Federal Government Operating Status|publisher=[[United States Office of Personnel Management]]|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> and schools were closed for two days.<ref>{{Cite news | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post_now/post/hurricane-sandy-causes-closings-cancellations-around-dc-region/2012/10/28/394edd54-2065-11e2-ba31-3083ca97c314_blog.html | title = Most schools, services resume after storm | date =October 31, 2012 | work = Washington Post}}</ref> [[MARC train]] and [[Virginia Railway Express]] were closed on October 30, and [[Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority|Metro]] rail and bus service were on Sunday schedule, opening at 2 p.m., until the system closes.<ref name=wtop>{{cite web|title=Sandy leaves behind outages, flooded roads|url=http://www.wtop.com/41/3097431/Sandy-leaves-behind-outages-flooded-roads|publisher=WTOP FM|accessdate=October 30, 2012}}</ref>
At least 100 feet (30 m) of a fishing pier in [[Ocean City, Maryland|Ocean City]] was destroyed. Governor Martin O'Malley said the pier was "half-gone".<ref>{{cite web|title=Sandy Damages Pier in Downtown Ocean City|url=http://www.wboc.com/story/19942184/sandy-damages-pier-in-downtown-ocean-city-md|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> Due to high winds, the [[Chesapeake Bay Bridge]] and the [[Millard E. Tydings Memorial Bridge]] on [[I-95]] were closed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Md-governor-Bay-Bridge-closing-to-traffic-3990795.php|title=Md. governor: Bay Bridge closing to traffic|publisher=[[SFGate]]|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> During the storm, the Mayor of [[Salisbury, Maryland|Salisbury]] instituted a Civil Emergency and a curfew.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.citylivingsalisbury.com/cityfiles/emergency/declaration2012.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121030121436/http://www.citylivingsalisbury.com/cityfiles/emergency/declaration2012.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=October 30, 2012 |title=Declaration of Civil Emergency |publisher=City of Salisbury, Maryland |accessdate=October 29, 2012 }}</ref> [[Interstate 68]] in far western Maryland and northern [[West Virginia]] closed due to heavy snow, stranding multiple vehicles and requiring assistance from the [[Maryland National Guard|National Guard]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Sandy picks up speed, may make landfall in Delaware or southern NJ|url=http://www.delawareonline.com/viewart/20121029/NEWS/310290055/Obama-declares-Delaware-disaster-area-provide-help-wake-storm?odyssey=nav%7Chead|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> Workers in [[Howard County, Maryland|Howard County]] tried to stop a sewage overflow caused by a power outage October 30. Raw sewage spilled at a rate of 2 million gallons per hour. It was unclear how much sewage had flowed into the [[Little Patuxent River]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/10/31/us/tropical-weather-sandy/index.html|title=Sandy pummels West Virginia as grueling recovery begins on East Coast|accessdate=October 31, 2012|newspaper=CNN|date=November 1, 2012}}</ref> Over 311,000 people were left without power as a result of the storm.<ref name="SandySitRpt6"/>
=====Delaware===== [[File:Hurricane Sandy impacts Prime Hook National Wildlife Refuge (DE).jpg|thumb|Before and after image of flooding caused by Hurricane Sandy at [[Prime Hook National Wildlife Refuge]]]] By the afternoon of October 29, rainfall at [[Rehoboth Beach]] totaled {{convert|6.53|in|mm}}. Other precipitation reports include nearly {{convert|7|in|mm}} at [[Indian River Inlet]] and more than {{convert|4|in|mm}} in [[Dover, Delaware|Dover]] and [[Bear, Delaware|Bear]]. At 4 p.m. on October 29, [[Delmarva Power]] reported on its website that more than 13,900 customers in Delaware and portions of the [[Eastern Shore of Maryland]] had lost electric service as high winds brought down trees and power lines. About 3,500 of those were in [[New Castle County, Delaware|New Castle County]], 2,900 were in [[Sussex County, Delaware|Sussex]], and more than 100 were in [[Kent County, Delaware|Kent County]]. Some residents in Kent and Sussex Counties experienced power outages that lasted up to nearly six hours. At the peak of the storm, more than 45,000 customers in Delaware were without power.<ref name="SandySitRpt6"/> The [[Delaware Memorial Bridge]] speed limit was reduced to {{convert|25|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} and the two outer lanes in each direction were closed. Officials planned to close the span entirely if sustained winds exceeded {{convert|50|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. A wind gust of {{convert|64|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} was measured at [[Lewes, Delaware|Lewes]] just before 2:30 p.m. on October 29. [[Delaware Route 1]] was closed due to water inundation between [[Dewey Beach, Delaware|Dewey Beach]] and [[Fenwick Island, Delaware|Fenwick Island]]. In Dewey Beach, flood waters were {{convert|1|to|2|ft|m}} in depth.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sandy picks up speed, may make landfall in Delaware or southern NJ|date=October 29, 2012|url=http://www.firstcoastnews.com/news/article/280175/29/Sandy-picks-up-speed-may-make-landfall-in-Delaware-or-southern-NJ|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130123062002/http://www.firstcoastnews.com/news/article/280175/29/Sandy-picks-up-speed-may-make-landfall-in-Delaware-or-southern-NJ|archivedate=January 23, 2013|df=}}</ref> Following the impact in Delaware, President Barack Obama declared the entire state a [[federal disaster area]], providing money and agencies for disaster relief in the wake of Hurricane Sandy.<ref>{{cite web|title=President Declares Disaster for Delaware|url=https://www.fema.gov/news-release/president-declares-disaster-delaware-0|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121117231655/https://www.fema.gov/news-release/president-declares-disaster-delaware-0|dead-url=yes|archive-date=November 17, 2012}}</ref>
=====New Jersey===== {{main|Effects of Hurricane Sandy in New Jersey}} [[File:121030-F-AL508-081c Aerial views during an Army search and rescue mission show damage from Hurricane Sandy to the New Jersey coast, Oct. 30, 2012.jpg|thumb|Damage to [[Mantoloking, New Jersey]]]] A 50-foot (15 m) piece of the Atlantic City Boardwalk washed away. Half the city of [[Hoboken, New Jersey|Hoboken]] flooded; the city of 50,000 had to evacuate two of its fire stations, the EMS headquarters, and the hospital. With the city cut off from area hospitals and fire suppression mutual aid, the city's Mayor asked for [[New Jersey National Guard|National Guard]] help.<ref name="bigstory"/> In the early morning of October 30, authorities in [[Bergen County, New Jersey|Bergen County]], New Jersey, evacuated residents after a [[berm]] overflowed and flooded several communities. Police Chief of Staff Jeanne Baratta said there were up to five feet (1.5 m) of water in the streets of [[Moonachie, New Jersey|Moonachie]] and [[Little Ferry, New Jersey|Little Ferry]]. The state Office of Emergency Management said rescues were undertaken in [[Carlstadt, New Jersey|Carlstadt]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Thousands of people may need to be rescued from New Jersey dam break, Bergen County Police Chief of Staff says|url=http://www.breakingnews.com/item/ahZzfmJyZWFraW5nbmV3cy13d3ctaHJkcg0LEgRTZWVkGILpnwsM/2012/10/30/thousands-of-people-may-need-to-be-rescued-from-new-jersey-dam-break|publisher=CNN|accessdate=October 30, 2012}}</ref> Baratta said the three towns had been "devastated" by the flood of water.<ref>{{cite news|title=Levee breaks in Northern New Jersey, floods three towns|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/30/us-levee-moonachie-break-idUSBRE89T0L020121030|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=October 30, 2012|date=October 30, 2012}}</ref> At the peak of the storm, more than 2,600,000 customers were without power.<ref name="SandySitRpt6"/> There were 43 Hurricane Sandy-related deaths in the state of New Jersey.<ref name="Diakakis et al 2013"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/11/16/us-storm-sandy-deaths-idUSBRE8AF0ZX20121116|title=Factbox: Storm Sandy blamed for at least 132 deaths in U.S., Canada|last=Osterman|first=Cynthia|date=November 16, 2012|publisher=Reuters}}</ref> Damage in the state was estimated at $36.8 billion.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/07/13/world/americas/hurricane-sandy-fast-facts|publisher=CNN|accessdate=November 27, 2013|date=July 13, 2013|title=Hurricane Sandy Fast Facts}}</ref>
=====Pennsylvania===== [[File:Hurricane Sandy downed tree Kutztown PA.jpg|thumb|Downed tree in [[Kutztown, Pennsylvania]]]]
[[Philadelphia]] Mayor [[Michael Nutter]] said the city would have no mass transit operations on any lines October 30.<ref name="ens-newswire"/> All major highways in and around the city of Philadelphia were closed on October 29 during the hurricane, including [[Interstate 95 in Pennsylvania|Interstate 95]], the [[Blue Route]] portion of [[Interstate 476]], the [[Vine Street Expressway]], [[Schuylkill Expressway]] ([[Interstate 76 (east)|I-76]]), and the Roosevelt Expressway; [[U.S. Route 1 in Pennsylvania|U.S. Route 1]].<ref name=wpvi>{{cite news|title=Philadelphia area highways, bridges shut down|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wpvi/story?section=news/local&id=8864405|work=[[WPVI-TV]]|date=October 29, 2012 |accessdate=October 30, 2012}}</ref> The highways reopened at 4 a.m. on October 30.<ref name=wpvi/> The [[Delaware River Port Authority]] also closed its major crossings over the [[Delaware River]] between Pennsylvania and New Jersey due to high winds, including the [[Commodore Barry Bridge]], the [[Walt Whitman Bridge]], the [[Ben Franklin Bridge]] and the [[Betsy Ross Bridge]].<ref name=wpvi/> Trees and powerlines were downed throughout [[Altoona Pennsylvania|Altoona]], and four buildings partially collapsed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.altoonamirror.com/page/content.detail/id/565627/-Updated-11-45-p-m---Thousands-still-without-power.html|title=Thousands still without power|work=The Altoona Mirror|accessdate=July 22, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160817234009/http://www.altoonamirror.com/page/content.detail/id/565627/-Updated-11-45-p-m---Thousands-still-without-power.html|archivedate=August 17, 2016|df=}}</ref> More than 1.2 million were left without power.<ref name="bigstory.ap.org"/> The [[Pennsylvania Emergency Management Agency]] reported 14 deaths believed to be related to Sandy.<ref>{{cite news|title=Death toll from Sandy now 96 in U.S|url=http://news.blogs.cnn.com/2012/11/02/sandys-damages-estimated-at-as-much-as-50-billion/ |publisher=CNN|accessdate=November 2, 2012|date=November 2, 2012}}</ref>
=====New York===== {{main|Effects of Hurricane Sandy in New York}} [[File:NJ-NY lights comparison.png|thumb|[[Suomi NPP]] satellite imagery showing the power outages in New York and New Jersey on November 1 compared to October 21.]]
[[New York governor]] [[Andrew Cuomo]] called [[New York National Guard|National Guard]] members to help in the state. Storm impacts in [[Upstate New York]] were much more limited than in [[New York City]]; there was some flooding and a few downed trees.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/viewart/20121030/NEWS01/310300037/Rochester-Sandy-fallen-trees|title=Storm takes a toll on area trees|publisher=[[Democrat and Chronicle]]|accessdate=October 30, 2012}}</ref> [[Rochester, New York|Rochester]] area utilities reported slightly fewer than 19,000 customers without power, in seven counties.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/viewart/20121029/NEWS01/310290040/Power-outages-Rochester-area|title=Power outages in the Rochester area|publisher=[[Democrat and Chronicle]]|accessdate=October 30, 2012}}</ref> In the state as a whole, however, more than 2,000,000 customers were without power at the peak of the storm.<ref name="SandySitRpt6"/>
[[Mayor of New York City]] [[Michael Bloomberg]] announced that [[New York City]] public schools would be closed on Tuesday, October 30 and Wednesday, October 31, but they remained closed through Friday, November 2.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hurricane Sandy closures|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/hurricane_sandy_closures_5ePbnf7aCmlUHSOgnP6hGP|publisher=New York Post|accessdate=October 29, 2012|date=October 29, 2012}}</ref> [[CUNY]] and [[NYU]] canceled all classes and campus activities for October 30.<ref>{{cite news |title=Follow live Hurricane Sandy updates from around the city|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/national/hurricane_sandy_could_wreak_havoc_LXtmRoECZiHJqnsgxqgxZL |publisher=New York Post|accessdate=October 29, 2012|first1=Yoav|last1=Gonen|first2=Sally|last2=Goldenberg|first3=David K.|last3=Li|first4=Amy|last4=Stretten|first5=Jessica|last5=Simeone|first6=Amber|last6=Sutherland|first7=Lorena|last7=Mongelli|first8=Larry|last8=Celona|first9=Antonio|last9=Antenucci|date=October 30, 2012}}</ref> The [[New York Stock Exchange]] was closed for trading for two days, the first weather closure of the exchange since 1985.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/money/la-fi-mo-stock-market-closed-on-tuesday-20121029,0,6584599.story|title=Stock market to remain closed Tuesday|last=Andrew|first=Tangel|date=October 29, 2012|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=October 29, 2012}}</ref> It was also the first two-day weather closure since the Great [[Blizzard of 1888]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://marketday.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/10/29/14778477-hurricane-sandy-to-keep-stock-markets-shuttered-tuesday?lite |title=Hurricane Sandy to keep stock markets shuttered Tuesday, Market Day |date=October 29, 2012 |accessdate=October 29, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121030044444/http://marketday.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/10/29/14778477-hurricane-sandy-to-keep-stock-markets-shuttered-tuesday?lite |archivedate=October 30, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
The East River overflowed its banks, flooding large sections of [[Lower Manhattan]]. [[Battery Park]] had a water surge of 13.88 ft.<ref>{{cite web|last=Long |first=Colleen |url=http://www.thestate.com/2012/10/29/2499940/nyc-waters-rise-to-irene-levels.html |title=Water, fire and darkness: NYC after the superstorm |publisher=TheState.com |date=October 29, 2012 |accessdate=October 30, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121101080214/http://www.thestate.com/2012/10/29/2499940/nyc-waters-rise-to-irene-levels.html |archivedate=November 1, 2012 |df= }}</ref> Seven subway tunnels under the [[East River]] were flooded.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tracking Storm Sandy Recovery|url=http://live.reuters.com/Event/Tracking_Storm_Sandy/54277687|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=October 30, 2012}}</ref> The [[Metropolitan Transportation Authority]] said that the destruction caused by the storm was the worst disaster in the 108-year history of the New York City subway system.<ref>{{cite web|title=Worst disaster in NYC subway's history, says MTA chief |url=http://www.theborneopost.com/2012/10/30/worst-disaster-in-nyc-subways-history-says-mta-chief |publisher=The Borneo Post |accessdate=October 3, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140713093803/http://www.theborneopost.com/2012/10/30/worst-disaster-in-nyc-subways-history-says-mta-chief/ |archivedate=July 13, 2014 |df= }}</ref> Sea water flooded the [[Ground Zero]] construction site.<ref>{{cite news|title=Superstorm Sandy: flood, wind damage and travel chaos in New York City|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/picturegalleries/worldnews/9643442/Superstorm-Sandy-flood-wind-damage-and-travel-chaos-in-New-York-City.html?frame=2382855|publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=October 30, 2012|date=October 30, 2012|location=London}}</ref> Over 10 billion gallons of raw and partially treated sewage were released by the storm, 94% of which went into waters in and around New York and New Jersey.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/01/nyregion/hurricane-sandy-sent-billions-of-gallons-of-sewage-into-waterways.html|title=Report Cites Large Release of Sewage From Hurricane Sandy|date=May 1, 2013|work=The New York Times|accessdate=July 22, 2016}}</ref> In addition, a four-story Chelsea building's facade crumbled and collapsed, leaving the interior on full display; however, no one was hurt by the falling masonry.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.oregonlive.com/today/index.ssf/2012/10/hurricane_sandy_large_sections.html |title=Hurricane Sandy: Large sections of Manhattan left without power |date=October 29, 2012 |accessdate=November 4, 2012 |work=The Oregonian}}</ref> The Atlantic Ocean storm surge also caused considerable flood damage to homes, buildings, roadways, boardwalks and mass transit facilities in low-lying coastal areas of the outer boroughs of [[Queens]], [[Brooklyn]] and [[Staten Island]].
After receiving many complaints that holding the marathon would divert needed resources, Mayor Bloomberg announced late afternoon November 2 that the [[New York City Marathon]] had been canceled. The event was to take place on Sunday, November 4. Marathon officials said that they did not plan to reschedule.<ref>{{cite web |title=NYC Marathon Won't Be Held Sunday: Officials |url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/NYC-Marathon-Post-Storm-Resources-Mayor-Bloomberg-Defends-Decision-177019721.html |publisher=WNBC TV |accessdate=November 2, 2012}}</ref>
Gas shortages throughout the region led to an effort by the U.S. federal government to bring in gasoline and set up mobile truck distribution at which people could receive up to 10 gallons of gas, free of charge. This caused lines of up to 20 blocks long and was quickly suspended.<ref>{{cite news |title=Fractured Recovery Divides the Region |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/04/nyregion/fractured-recovery-a-week-after-hurricane-sandy.html?hpw |publisher=The New York Times |accessdate=November 9, 2012 |first1=James |last1=Barron |first2=Sam |last2=Dolnick |first3=Michael |last3=Schwirtz |date=November 3, 2012}}</ref> On Thursday, November 8, Mayor Bloomberg announced [[odd-even rationing]] of gasoline would be in effect beginning November 9 until further notice.<ref>{{cite news |title=New York City and Long Island Impose Odd-Even Gas Rationing |url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/11/08/bloomberg-imposes-odd-even-gas-rationing/ |publisher=The New York Times |accessdate=November 9, 2012 |first=Andy |last=Newman |date=November 8, 2012}}</ref>
On November 26, Governor Cuomo called Sandy "more impactful" than Hurricane Katrina, and estimated costs to New York at $42 billion.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/27/nyregion/governor-cuomo-says-hurricane-sandy-was-worse-than-katrina.html|title=Cuomo, in Aid Appeal, Cites Broad Reach of Storm|date=November 26, 2012|accessdate=December 2, 2012|work=The New York Times|first1=Thomas|last1=Kaplan|first2=Raymond|last2=Hernandez}}</ref> Approximately 100,000 residences on Long Island were destroyed or severely damaged, including 2,000 that were rendered uninhabitable.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsday.com/long-island/officials-sandy-destroys-more-than-2-000-li-homes-1.4316744|title=Officials: Sandy destroys more than 2,000 LI homes Newsday December 10, 2012|work=Newsday|accessdate=October 4, 2014}}</ref> There were 53 Hurricane Sandy-related deaths in the state of New York.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6220a1.htm|title=Deaths Associated with Hurricane Sandy — October–November 2012|date=May 24, 2013|access-date=May 11, 2017|work=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report|authors=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention}}</ref> In 2016, the hurricane was determined to have been the worst to strike the New York City area since at least 1700.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/hurricane-sandy-worst-storm-new-york-since-1700-2016-10|title=New research shows Hurricane Sandy was the worst storm to hit New York since at least 1700|date=October 28, 2016|accessdate=October 29, 2016|work=Business Insider|first1=Rafi|last=Letzter}}</ref>

recorded on outer [[Cape Cod]] and [[Buzzards Bay]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wcvb.com/weather/Highest-Winds-from-Sandy-in-Massachusetts/-/9850416/17189430/-/format/rsss_2.0/-/6p2n7f/-/index.html |archive-date=February 9, 2013 |title=Highest Winds from Sandy in Massachusetts |publisher=WCVB.com |accessdate=October 30, 2012 }}</ref> Nearly 300,000 customers were without power in
